depictions.title: Totenbeschaubefund des Kristean Aksenti vom 06. Februar 1918 (Copyright Metropolis von Austria)

description.value: Kristean Aksenti wurde 1851/52 in der Ortschaft Unter-Wikow geboren. Er war Landwirt. Kristean Aksenti starb am 06. Februar 1918 im Spital des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn an Lungentuberkulose. Er wurde am 06. Februar 1918 beschaut und sollte am 08. Februar 1918 beerdigt werden. -------------- Kristean Aksenti was born in 1851/52 in the village of Unter-Wikow. He was a farmer. Kristean Aksenti died of pulmonary tuberculosis on the 6th of February 1918 in the hospital of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn. He was examined on the 06th of February 1918 and was to be buried on the 08th of February 1918.

description.value: Vasilije Aleksić (1813-1877) was a Serbian merchant from Vršac (today Serbia) and a close friend and associate of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) during his exile in Vienna (1842-1858). He was the owner of the silk store "zum Fürsten Milosch" from 1843 to 1846 (Graben 11, 1010 Vienna). Vasilije Aleksić died at the age of 64 on 7 March 1877 in Danilo Žefarović's house in Fleischmarkt 16 (1010 Vienna) and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).

types.description:
This research project focuses on one of the aspects of the history and presence of Orthodox Christians, and in particular of the Orthodox Serbs, in Vienna. Quite often the opinion emerges in the contemporary public discourse that the Orthodox Christians have come to Austria for the first time in the wake of the so-called "Gastarbeiterbewegung" of the 1960s and 1970s. However, their history and presence in Austria dates well back to the 17th century. In fact, according to the Austro-Hungarian population census of 1910, more than 2,000,000 Serbs lived in the Habsburg monarchy: in Hungary a total of 1,106,471, in Bosnia and Herzegovina 825,338 and in Dalmatia 105,000.
This research project uses biographical data on the Orthodox Serbs in Vienna in the period from 1741 until 1918 in order to illustrate how the Orthodox began to migrate to the Habsburg Empire, how Orthodox merchants settled in Vienna and how they integrated into Viennese society of that time. On the basis of meticulously researched data in Austrian archives the life of famous Serbs in Vienna is reconstructed. Their places of dwelling and action are localised and embedded into a customised OpenAtlas database with an online Geoportal, which will be open to the interested public at the end of the project.
This project aims to gain a better understanding of contemporary developments and future trends in Orthodox Christianity based on scholarly research on famous Serbian personalities of the 18th and 19th centuries in detail, which were already integrated into Austrian society at that time in Vienna as well as in Austria in general.
types.label: A Digital Geoportal of the History of the Serbs in Vienna 1741-1918

description.value: Jovan Aleksić von Maina (1783-1861) was an Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman of Serbian origin. Aleksić was born in Kotor (today Montenegro, in Italian Cattaro) in a noble family, whose ancestors had moved from the Montenegrin mountains to the Boka Kotorska in 1621. The family of Aleksić von Maina bore five captains, two majors, two colonels and two generals. They served in the armed forces of Venice, France and Austria. Jovan's uncle Rade Maina was promoted to the rank of General in the Republic of the Venice in 1779. Jovan Aleksić von Maina was, following the service in the Venetian army, also in the French army under Napoleon Bonaparte (1769-1821). From 1815 he joined the Austrian army, where he was promoted to the rank of General in Sremska Mitrovica in 1835. He was awarded the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd grade. He was ennobled and elevated to knighthood (Ritterstand) in 1840. After his retirement in 1844, when he was promoted to the rank of Field marshal-lieutenant, he moved to Vienna, where he stayed for the next eleven years. He lived at first (already before 1853) in Johannesgasse 969 (the so-called "Fleischhof", today Johannesgasse 1, 1010 Vienna).  His wife Marija Aleksić von Maina (born Klaić) died in this house on 21 December 1857 at the age of 54. She was buried on the St. Marx cemetery, then exhumated and transferred to Hietzing cemetery in 1899. Jovan Aleksić von Maina died on 19 February 1861 in the house No. 618 ("Trattnerhof", Graben 29-29a / Trattnerhof 1/2, 1010 Vienna) and was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 22 February 1861.

description.value: Teodor Aleksić von Maina (1825-1891) was an Austrian general and nobleman of Serbian origin. Aleksić was born in Palermo in a noble family, whose ancestors had moved from Montenegrin mountains to the Boka Kotorska in 1621. The family of Aleksić von Maina bore five captains, two majors, two colonels and two generals. They served in the armed forces of Venice, France and Austria. His father's uncle Rade Maina was promoted to the rank of General in the Republic of Venice in 1779. Teodor's father Jovan Aleksić von Maina was promoted to the rank of the General in the Austrian army in 1835. In 1849 Teodor Aleksić von Maina was awarded with the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class. And in 1858 he married Anastasija (Stana) Obrenović, the daughter of Jovan Obrenović (1787-1850) and the niece of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). They had three daughters. In 1863 he became an adjutant of the Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916). He remained in this position until 1866 and was promoted to the rank of Major. Teodor Aleksić von Maina was awarded with the Knight's Cross (with swords) of the Order of Duke Adolph I of Nassau in 1863. He was promoted to the rank of Colonel on 7 April 1866, while he served in the 4th Infantry Regiment in Slunj (today in Croatia). Teodor Aleksić von Maina died in Novi Sad (today in Serbia) in 1891. He was the last male descendant of the house Aleksić von Maina.

description.value:
Aleksandar Andrić (1816-1876) joined the Military Academy in Vienna and graduated in 1832. He was an officer in the Austrian army in the Military Frontier until 1850. After that he received a pension in the rank of Sub-lieutenant. Andrić was also a writer and published his poems and novels from 1840. He is mostly known for editing his journal "Svetovid", first in Timișoara (today in Romania) in 1852 and at the end of that year in Vienna until 1859. He also published "Svetozar" as addition to "Svetovid" and from 13 July to 12 October 1856 as a separate edition. Apart from the newspaper, Andrić printed two of his books in Vienna, namely a history of Montenegro entitled "Geschichte des Fürstenthums Montenegro von den ältesten Zeiten bis zum Jahre 1852" in 1853 and the Slavic Calender entitled "Österreichischer Slaven-Kalender für das Jahr 1858" in 1857. Moreover, he printed his calender "Zimzelen" for the years 1858, 1859 and 1860. 
In May 1859 he was accused of anti-Austrian propaganda. His journal was banned for the next three months, and Andrić fled to Serbia. Later he was sentenced to six months in prison. The reason for this was his poem on Montenegro. After 1859 he moved to Belgrade, where he continued to publish "Svetovid" and also other books in his publishing house. He was a member of the "Srpsko učeno društvo" (today the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts) and of the "Matica Srpska". He died in Bucharest in 1876.

depictions.title: Tombstone of the Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman Sava Arlov

description.value: Sava Arlov (1827-1903) was an Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman. He was born in the Military Frontier in Petrinja (today Croatia) on 26 October 1827. In 1848 he joined the Austrian army. After the Battle of Custozza (1866) he was decorated with the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class (Orden der Eisernen Krone 3. Klasse mit Kriegsdekoration). On 12 June 1867 he was ennobled and elevated to knighthood (Ritterstand) by the Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916). In 1882 Sava Arlov was decorated with the Knight's Cross of the Order of Leopold (Ritterkreuz des Leopold Ordens). He was promoted to the rank of Major General in 1883 and to the rank of Field marshal-lieutenant in 1887. In 1888, on the occasion of his 40 year jubilee in the Austrian army, he was decorated by Emperor Franz Joseph I with the Order of the Iron Crown 2nd class (Orden der Eisernen Krone 2. Klasse mit Kriegsdekoration). Soon after that he retired and died in his apartment in Posthorngasse 5 (1030 Vienna) on 30 May 1903. After the memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt 13 (1010 Vienna) he was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 2 June 1903.

depictions.title: Ivan Arnovljević (1869-1951)

description.value: Ivan Arnovljević (1869-1951) was a Serbian scientist and Professor at the University of Belgrade. He was born on 7 March 1869 in Kikinda (today Serbia) and, after attending the grammar school in Kikinda and Novi Sad, he studied at the "Technische Hochschule" (today "Technische Universität Wien"/Vienna University of Technology) in Vienna from 1886 to 1892. Arnovljević received his PhD on 25 April 1910 in Vienna. His dissertation is entitled "Der eingespannte auf Druck und Biegung beanspruchte Stab". After his studies he worked as an engineer in different private offices for the construction of bridges in Vienna from 1894 to 1905 (namely Wagner, Biró, L&j Biró & A. Kurz). In 1905 Arnovljević started to work in the "K.K. Direktion für den Bau der Wasserstraßen". In his memoirs the Serbian mathematician Milutin Milanković (1879-1958) mentioned his friend and colleguae Arnovljević as one of the first Serbian doctors of technical sciences. Based on Milanković's sugegstion In 1910 Dr. Ivan Arnovljević was elected for Professor of Mechanics at the Technical Faculty of the University of Belgrade in 1910. His main scientific interest were problems concerning stresses in steel girders and coupled systems. His teaching at University dealt mainly with the fields of mechanics, geometry and statics. Arnovljević kept his chair at University until his retirement in 1939, but he continued to teach until 1941. He was elected as corresponding member of the Serbian Academy of Sciences ("Srpska akademija nauka") in 1948. Ivan Arnovljević died in Belgrade on 9 November 1951.

depictions.title: Dimitrije Avramović
Dimitrije Avramović (1815-1855)
Portrait of Vuk Stefanović Karadžić by Dimitrije Avramović (1840)

description.value: Dimitrije Avramović (1815-1855) was a Serbian painter and writer, one of the most important Serbian painters in the first half of the 19th century. He was born in Šajkaši (today Serbia) on 15 March 1815. Avramović was one of the first explorers of the Holy Mount Athos in 1846. He wrote two books on the Serbian Hilandar Monastery and the Serbian cultural treasures there  ("Описаније древности србски у Светој (Атонској) Гори с XIII литографних таблица" in 1847 and "Света гора са стране вере, художества и повеснице описана Димитрием Аврамовићем живописцем" in 1848). He studied at the Viennese Academy of Fine Arts (then in the Annakloster, 1010 Vienna) from 1836 to 1840. Being a friend of the Serbian philologist and linguist Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864), he painted his portrait in Vienna in 1840. This painting (oil on canvas) is preserved today in the Serbian National Museum ("Narodni Muzej") in Belgrade. He painted also the iconostases in many Serbian Orthodox Churches. The most valuable is the iconostasis in the St. Michael's Cathedral ("Saborna Crkva") in Belgrade (1841-1845). From 1852 he lived in Novi Sad, where he died on 1 March 1855.

depictions.title: Title Page of the Avramović Dictionary (1791)

description.value: Teodor Avramović (1757-1815) was a Serbian teacher, writer and school inspector in the Habsburg Empire, proofreader and author of the largest and most important Serbian-German dictionary in the 18th century, the so-called "Avramović Dictionary" with about 20,000 words. The dictionary (in German entitled "Deutsch und Illyrisches Wörterbuch zum Gebrauch der Illyrischen Nation in den K. K. Staaten"; in Slavonic-Serbian entitled "Нѣмецкïй и сербскïй словарь на потребу сербскагo народа в ъкрал. Державахъ") was printed in 1791 in the printing house of Josef Kurzböck (1736-1792), where Avramović was proofreader for Cyrillic books since 1786. In 1791/92 he was an official in the Illyrian Court Office ("Illyrische Hofkanzlei").

depictions.title: Family Tomb of Djordje Ostojić in the Viennese Central Cemetery

description.value: Dušan von Bajić (1881-1909) was the son of Teodor von Bajić. He was a merchant and after the death of his grandfather Djordje Ostojić the owner of the company "Baich & Ostoits" in Vienna. He was decorated with the Mariannenkreuz des Deutschen Ritterordens. Dušan Bajić invested also in a car factory. He committed suicide on 21 May 1909 in his home in Hainburgerstraße 21 (1030 Vienna). After that his company went bankrupt. He was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 24 May 1909.

description.value:
Jovan von Bajić (1841-1893) was a Viennese merchant and cattle dealer. He was one of the founders of the company "Gebrüder Baich" together with his brothers Teodor and Luka in 1877. This company was dissolved in 1892. His father's grandfather, Jovan Bajić, was ennobled in 1791.
Jovan von Bajić married Desanka Polit (1853-1939). Already in the Cataster from 1869 the brothers Luka and Jovan von Bajić are mentioned as owners of the house in Simmeringer Hauptstraße 46 and Am Kanal 37 (it is the same object with entrances on both streets). The old Cataster number was Hauptstraße No. 277. This building still exists. Jovan and Luka von Bajić donated 300 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna. Jovan von Bajić died on 5 September 1893 in Schützengasse 17 (1030 Vienna).

types.description:
This research project focuses on one of the aspects of the history and presence of Orthodox Christians, and in particular of the Orthodox Serbs, in Vienna. Quite often the opinion emerges in the contemporary public discourse that the Orthodox Christians have come to Austria for the first time in the wake of the so-called "Gastarbeiterbewegung" of the 1960s and 1970s. However, their history and presence in Austria dates well back to the 17th century. In fact, according to the Austro-Hungarian population census of 1910, more than 2,000,000 Serbs lived in the Habsburg monarchy: in Hungary a total of 1,106,471, in Bosnia and Herzegovina 825,338 and in Dalmatia 105,000.
This research project uses biographical data on the Orthodox Serbs in Vienna in the period from 1741 until 1918 in order to illustrate how the Orthodox began to migrate to the Habsburg Empire, how Orthodox merchants settled in Vienna and how they integrated into Viennese society of that time. On the basis of meticulously researched data in Austrian archives the life of famous Serbs in Vienna is reconstructed. Their places of dwelling and action are localised and embedded into a customised OpenAtlas database with an online Geoportal, which will be open to the interested public at the end of the project.
This project aims to gain a better understanding of contemporary developments and future trends in Orthodox Christianity based on scholarly research on famous Serbian personalities of the 18th and 19th centuries in detail, which were already integrated into Austrian society at that time in Vienna as well as in Austria in general.

depictions.title: Tomb of the Family Bajić
Tomb of the Family Bajić, Detail

description.value:
Luka von Bajić (1839-1907) was a cattle dealer, who lived in Vienna for more than 40 years. He was one of the founders of the company "Gebrüder Baich" together with his brothers Teodor and Jovan in 1877. This company was dissolved in 1892. Already in the Cataster from 1869 the brothers Luka and Jovan von Bajić are mentioned as owners of the house in Simmeringer Hauptstraße 46 and Am Kanal 37 (it is the same object with entrances on both streets). The old Cataster number was Hauptstraße No. 277. This building still exists. Jovan and Luka von Bajić donated 300 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna. 
His father's grandfather, Jovan Bajić, was ennobled in 1791. Luka von Bajić was a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna as well as its President from 6 September 1894 until 1897. The company of Luka von Bajić for cattle trade was located on Zentralviehmarkt (1030 Vienna) and was registered on 17 March 1901. Before that he was also registered as importer of cattle from 11 October 1898. Luka von Bajić was deleted from the register after his death in 1907. His company continued to work under his son Petar von Bajić. In 1899 Luka sold together with Milan, Ljubica and Desanka von Bajić a house in Schützengasse 17 (1030 Vienna) (still exists). Luka von Bajić died on 23 March 1907 at the age of 67 in his apartment in Barichgasse 3 (1030 Vienna) (does not exist anymore). He was buried in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 25 March 1907. 
His wife Ljubica was born in the family Ostojić. Luka's son, Teodor von Bajić (1870-1895) died on 8 May 1895 at the age of 25 in the house Schützengasse 17 (1030 Vienna).

description.value: Milan von Bajić (1880-1909) was a son of the Viennese merchant Jovan von Bajić (1841-1893). He was born in Simmering on 25 August 1880. Milan von Bajić was also a merchant and one of the owners of the Company "Erste Schwechater Schrauben-, Nieten- und Schmiedewarenfabrik Nemeczek&Baich". The Company was founded in 1908 and produced ironwork. Milan von Bajić died in the Viennese Sanatorium Am Steinhof (today Otto Wagner Spital, 1140 Vienna) on 29 January 1909.

description.value: Stefan von Bajić was born in Sremska Mitrovica in 1806. He moved to Vienna with his family in the 1840s, where he built a house, which still exists in Simmering Hauptstraße 46 (1110 Vienna). He died in this house on 6 May 1870 and was buried two days later in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His remains were moved to the tomb of the family Bajić in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) in 1897.

description.value:
Teodor von Bajić (1846-1897) was a Viennese cattle dealer and one of the founders of the company "Gebrüder Baich" together with his brothers Jovan and Luka in 1877. This company was dissolved in 1892. In 1896 he was the founder of the company for cattle trade "Baich & Ostoits" together with his father in law Djordje Ostojić. The company's address was Hainburgerstrasse 21 (1030 Vienna, still exists) and Zentralviehmarkt (1030 Vienna). The comapny donated 300 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna. His father's grandfather, Jovan Bajić, was ennobled in 1791. Teodor von Bajić was a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Cuncil of St. Sava in Vienna. He lived in Hainburgerstraße 21 (1030 Vienna). 
Teodor von Bajić died in the Sanatorium Löw (Mariannengasse 20, 1090 Vienna, still exists) on 26 March 1897 at the age of 50 and was buried on 28 March in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof) in 1110 Vienna. On 22 February 1898 Teodor von Bajić was deleted from the commercial register after his death and Djordje Ostojić was appointed as the only owner of the company. He died on 19 November 1901 at the age of 70 and was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).on 20 November 1901. In 1902 Djordje Ostojić was deleted from the commercial register and his successors were Zora von Bajić (Djordje's daughter and Teodor's wife) and Dušan von Bajić (Teodor's and Zora's son).

description.value: Zacharias Balan wurde 1878 in Petrouz an der Sereth geboren. Er war Landwirt. Er starb am 11. Juli 1918 im Spital des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn an Lungentuberkulose. Er wurde am 11. Juli 1918 beschaut und er sollte am 11. Juli 1918 beerdigt werden. -------------- Zacharias Balan was born in 1878 in the village of Petrouz on the Sereth. He was a farmer. He died of pulmonary tuberculosis on the 11th of July 1918 in the hospital of refugee camp Oberhollabrunn. He was examined on the 11th of July 1918 and he was to be buried on the 11th of July 1918.

depictions.title: Tomb of Velimir Barbarić in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof)

description.value: Velimir Barbarić (1823-1902) was secretary of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna and one of the initiators of the founding of this community in 1860. He was also a member of the delegation which was in audience to Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) on 13 December 1860. This delegation thanked the Emperor for his approval for the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Community of St. Sava. Velimir Barbarić had the title of "Regierungsrat" and was "Oberdirektor am k. u .k. Obersten Gerichts- und Kassationshof". Since 1860 he was court translator for the Serbian and Croatian language and since 2 January 1881 he had the title of "Hofrat". He lived in Untere Donaustraße 23 (1020 Vienna). Velimir Barbarić died on 18 November 1902 at the age of 80. He was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 20 November 1902.

description.value:
Jovan Barbulović was the owner of a factory for French ties. He received a privilege for this kind of trade on 27 October 1845. Therefore, he founded his company entitled "Barbulowits Joh. D" for textiles and men's wear in 1846. Its address at that time was in Vienna's city centre, namely house No. 589 (that is Bauernmarkt 2a, 1010 Vienna, does not exist anymore). Jovan Barbulović was exporting his products even to Italy and the Orient. 
In 1848 his company was to be found in Bauernmarkt No. 581 (that is Bauernmarkt 11, 1010 Vienna, does not exist anymore) and, apart from ties, he was selling also shirts, collars, gloves, hats, braces, etc. His motto was “Eleganz, Solidität, Billigkeit". In 1849 he moved to the first floor of the house Graben No. 619 (the so-called "Elephantenhaus", does not exist anymore, today Stock-im-Eisen-Platz). In 1857 his company situated in Ungargasse No. 364 (today Ungargasse 5, 1030 Vienna, still exists) and was deleted from the commercial register in January 1860.

depictions.title: Portrait Photograph of Countess Anna-Anka Bienerth-Schmerling
Tomb of the Noble Family Bienerth-Schmerling

description.value: Countess (Gräfin) Anna-Anka Bienerth-Schmerling was born in the Serbian noble family of Lazarević de Nagy-Szrediste in Veliko Središte (today Serbia) on 1 February 1864. She married Count (Graf) Richard von Bienerth-Schmerling (1863-1918) in the Schottenkirche (1010 Vienna) on 7 January 1893. He was Prime Minister of the Austrian part of the Habsburg Empire from 1908 to 1911 and the grandson of Anton von Schmerling (1805-1893). Anka Bienerth was awarded with the title of Lady-in-waiting or Court lady (Palastdame) by Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) on 29 March 1909.  Before that, in 1908, she was decorated with the Order of Elizabeth 1st class. Anna-Anka Bienerth was well-known for her charitable work and was also very popular in the Viennese public life. In 1914 she founded the so-called "Schwarz-gelbes Kreuz", a charity organisation whose first president she was. Later, she was honorary president of the "Komitee für Kinderernährung und öffentliche Ausspeisung" (until 1926). For her charitable work Countess Anna-Anka Bienerth-Schmerling was awarded the Eiserne Salvatormedalle by the authorities of the City of Vienna in 1919. Her son Rudolf died in 1921 and her daughter Marie in 1935. She died in her apartment in Stadiongasse 2 (1010 Vienna) on 14 July 1937 and was buried in the family tomb in the Hietzing Cemetery (Hietzinger Friedhof, 1130 Vienna) two days later.

depictions.title: Valtazar Bogišić (1834-1908)

description.value: Valtazar Bogišić was an expert in Law as well as a sociologist and an ethnographer from a Serbian Catholic family from Cavtat (today Croatia). After attending grammar school in Venice, he studied Law in Munich, Vienna (1861-1863), Berlin and Paris. At the University of Gießen he received a PhD in Philosophy in 1862 and then a PhD in Law in Vienna in 1865. After that Bogišić stayed in Vienna, where he succeeded Franz Xaver Ritter von Miklosich (1813-1891) at his position in the Imperial Court Library ("Kaiserliche Hofbibliothek") in Vienna until 1868. He collected folk poems under the influence of the work done by Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864). Influenced by Panslavism he was one of the founders of the society "Slovenska beseda" in Vienna and of this society's library. From 1869 to 1872 Bogišić was Professor of Slavic Law at the University of Odessa. Later, he moved to Paris, but his main work was the codification of the Civil Law in Montenegro, where he was Minister of Justice (1893-1899). Bogišić was awarded with the Russian Order of St. Anna Order 2nd class, the Commander Cross of the French Legion of Merit, the Serbian Order of St. Sava 1st class and the Montenegrin Danilo Order 1st class. He was ennobled in Russia. In 1902 Valtazar Bogišić was elected as President of International Institute of Sociology.

types.description:
This research project focuses on one of the aspects of the history and presence of Orthodox Christians, and in particular of the Orthodox Serbs, in Vienna. Quite often the opinion emerges in the contemporary public discourse that the Orthodox Christians have come to Austria for the first time in the wake of the so-called "Gastarbeiterbewegung" of the 1960s and 1970s. However, their history and presence in Austria dates well back to the 17th century. In fact, according to the Austro-Hungarian population census of 1910, more than 2,000,000 Serbs lived in the Habsburg monarchy: in Hungary a total of 1,106,471, in Bosnia and Herzegovina 825,338 and in Dalmatia 105,000.
This research project uses biographical data on the Orthodox Serbs in Vienna in the period from 1741 until 1918 in order to illustrate how the Orthodox began to migrate to the Habsburg Empire, how Orthodox merchants settled in Vienna and how they integrated into Viennese society of that time. On the basis of meticulously researched data in Austrian archives the life of famous Serbs in Vienna is reconstructed. Their places of dwelling and action are localised and embedded into a customised OpenAtlas database with an online Geoportal, which will be open to the interested public at the end of the project.
This project aims to gain a better understanding of contemporary developments and future trends in Orthodox Christianity based on scholarly research on famous Serbian personalities of the 18th and 19th centuries in detail, which were already integrated into Austrian society at that time in Vienna as well as in Austria in general.

depictions.title: Totenbeschaubefund des Dumiton Bondaz vom 2. Februar 1917 (Copyright Metropolis von Austria)

description.value: Dumiton Bondaz wurde 1865 in Satulmare geboren. Er war Landwirt. Dumiton Bondaz litt an einem diffusen Bronchialkatarrh und starb am 1. Februar 1917 im Spital des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn an einer Herzparalyse. Er wurde am 2. Februar 1917 beschaut und sollte am 3. Februar 1917 beerdigt werden. ------------------ Dumiton Bondaz was born in Satulmare in 1865. He was a farmer. Dumiton Bondaz suffered from a diffuse bronchial catarrh and died on the 1st of February 1917 in the hospital of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn from a heart paralysis. He was examined on the 2nd of February 1917 and was to be buried on the 3rd of February 1917.

description.value: Svetozar Borojević von Bojna (1856-1920) was an Austrian Field marshal of Serbian origin. He was the only South Slav, who reached the highest rank in the Austro-Hungarian Army. Borojević was born in the Military Frontier in an officer's family. From 1887 to 1891 Borojević lectured Military tactics at the Theresian Military Academy ("Theresianische Militärakademie") in Wiener Neustadt. In 1913 he was promoted to the rank of a General of Infantry. The Infantry Regiment No. 51 was named in his honour. In the First World War (1914-1918) Borojević led successfully operations against the Italian Army at the Isonzo Front, first as Comnmander of the 5th Army. Later his troops were united under his name as "Army Group Borojević". Due to his military merits he was decorated with the Military Order of Maria Theresia and on 1 February 1918 he was promoted to the rank of Field marshal. He died in Klagenfurt on 23 May 1920, where he was buried. Upon demand of the last Austrian Emperor Karl I (1887-1922) his mortal remains were transferred to a grave of honor in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 27 October 1920. Several thousand officers of the former Austro-Hungarian Army were present at this funeral.

description.value:
Stefan Bosanac (1802-1871) was a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna and one of the initiators of the founding of this community in 1860. He was also a member of the delegation which was in audience to Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) on 13 December 1860. This delegation thanked the Emperor for his approval for the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Community of St. Sava.  
In July 1850 Stefan Bosanac was the founder of the Company "Bosanetz & Welicskovits" in Lazzenhof 1 (Bauernmarkt 21, 1010 Vienna) together with Jovan Veličković (1818-1863). The company was deleted from the commercial register on 14 November 1866. 
Stefan Bosanac died at the age of 69 on 30 August 1871 in Währinger Straße 35 (1180 Vienna, the original building does not exist anymore). He was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 2 September 1871.

depictions.title: Totenbeschaubefund des Grigori Bradazan vom 12. Januar 1918 (Copyright Metropolis von Austria)

description.value: Grigori Bradazan wurde 1849/50 in der Ortschaft Bucsoaia (im heutigen Rumänien) geboren. Er war Landwirt. Grigori Bradazan starb am 12. Januar 1918 im Spital des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn an einer chronischen Herzmuskelentzündung (Myocarditis chronica). Er wurde am 12. Januar 1918 beschaut und sollte am 14. Januar 1918 beerdigt werden. ------------- Grigori Bradazan was born in 1849/50 in the village of Bucsoaia (in today's Romania). He was a farmer. Grigori Bradazan died on the 12th of January 1918 in the hospital of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn of a chronic heart muscle inflammation (Myocarditis chronica). He was examined on the 12th of January 1918 and was to be buried on the 14th of January 1918.

description.value: Aleksandar Čokor (1815-1884) was born on 22 July 1815 in Baja (today Hungary) and came to Vienna, where he worked at the Northern Train Station ("Nordbahnhof"). He married Anna Schindler on 24 January 1847 in the Roman Catholic church of St. Leopold (1020 Vienna). Aleksandar Čokor's address was Leopoldstadt No. 702. Anna Schindler was born on 22 July 1818. She died on 3 July 1856 in the house Leopoldstadt No. 644 at the age of 38 and was buried on 5 July in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). Aleksandar Čokor's second wife Theresia died on 12 March 1859 at the age of 25 in the same house (Leopoldstadt No. 644). She was buried on 14 March in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). Aleksandar Čokor was the father of the scientist Jovan Čokor (1849-1911).

description.value:
Jovan Čokor (1849-1911) was born as Johann Nepomuk Csokor on 4 April 1849 and was baptised on 6 April in the Roman Catholic church of St. Leopold (1020 Vienna). He was born in the house No. 371 in Leopoldstadt (today Große Stadtgutgasse 11, 1020 Vienna). His father was Aleksandar Čokor (1815-1884) and his mother Anna Schindler (1818-1856). He started his education at Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) at his uncle the Archimandrite Julijan Čokor and stayed there from 1854 to 1864. After that he finished the grammar school in Pest in 1866 and continued to study medicine in Vienna. Jovan Čokor was promoted to Dr. of Medicine in 1873. In 1875 he graduated in Veterinary Science and gained a position as assistant at the Department of Anatomy and Physiology in Vienna. He gave lectures on Histology and Parasitology and introduced histological-microscopic teaching at the University. 

Jovan Čokor married Emilie Müller on 28 July 1877 in Vienna. They had five children: 
Emilie Sofia Maria Čokor (6 June 1878), 
Franz Theodor Čokor (8 September 1885 - 5 January 1969), 
Johann Čokor (22 October 1886 - 1915),
Eugenie Čokor (24 November 1887 - 1979),
Sofie Čokor (6 July 1891 - 1967). 

From 1876 as a temporary and from 1879 as a permanent Lecturer at the Chair of Zoology, Čokor was appointed as Professor of General Pathology and Forensic Veterinary Medicine in Vienna in 1880. In 1884 he deepened his knowledge by working together with Robert Koch (1843-1910) in Berlin. Already from 1889 he was also an eminent Professor of Infectious and Parasitic Diseases and turned more to parasitology. In 1906 a chair was established for this discipline. Čokor also founded and widely publicised diagnostic vaccine stations. In addition, he taught as a Privatdozent from 1890 and as a Professor of Veterinary Medicine from 1895 at the University of Vienna. In 1909 he retired as Professor. 
Jovan Čokor published regularly in several scientific journals, namely the "Österreichische Vierteljahresschrift für wissenschaftliche Veterinärkunde", "Allgemeine Wiener Medizinische Zeitung" and "Wiener Wochenschrift". He published a "Lehrbuch der gerichtlichen Thierheilkunde" (1898, 2nd ed. 1902). He received the Knight's Cross in 1898 and the Officer's Cross of the Franz Josef Order in 1909. He was Knight of the Serbian Order of Saint Sava and a member of the Society of Doctors as well as honorary member of the Serbian Society of Doctors in Belgrade. Finally, he bore the title of "Hofrat". Jovan Čokor died on 7 January 1911 in his apartment in Mödling (Jasomirgottgasse 8) and was buried on the local cemetery.

depictions.title: Vladimir Ćorović (1929)

description.value: Vladimir Ćorović (1885-1941) was one of the most important Serbian historians in the 20th century. He was born in Mostar (today Herzegovina) on 15 October 1885. After attending grammar school in Mostar, he studied Slavonic Philology and History at the University of Vienna from 1904 to 1908. Vladimir Ćorović received his PhD title on 24 June 1908. His dissertation entitled "Lukijan Mušicki. Eine Studie aus der serbischen Literaturgeschichte" is a scholarly work about the famous Serbian bishop and poet Lukijan Mušicki (1777-1837). Ćorović's professors were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923), Milan von Rešetar (1860-1942) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). During his entire studies in Vienna he lived in Alser Straße 55/20 (1090 Vienna). Ćorović was a member of the Serbian Students' Association "Zora", on which he wrote a book. From 1909 he lived in Sarajevo and was imprisoned from 1914 to 1917 based on accusations of high treason with many other Serbs. After that Vladimir Ćorović moved to Zagreb and in 1919 to Belgrade. In Belgrade he was Professor of History at the University of Belgrade and its Rector from 1934 to 1936. Ćorović was also a member of Serbian Royal Academy from 1922. His scholarly work focused on Serbian and Yugoslavi history in the 19th and 20th centuries. He died in a plain crash in Greece on 12 April 1941, when he was following the government of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia into exile after the German occupation of Yugoslavia.

depictions.title: Miloš Crnjanski in 1914

description.value: Miloš Crnjanski (1893-1977) was a Serbian poet, writer and diplomat born in Csongrád (today Hungary) on 26 October 1893. He grew up in Timișoara (today Romania), where he finished grammar school. In autumn 1913 he moved to Vienna, where he studied Medicine. In his work "Komentari" ("Comments") he described his Viennese days. He lived in Piaristengasse 54 (1080 Vienna) in the guesthouse of Mrs. Thiess. Crnjanski was a member of the Serbian Students' Association "Zora". His memoirs are very interesting, especially because of the events on and after 28 June 1914. Crnjanski played pool in Meinl Café on that day, when he heard the news about the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand (1863-1914) in Sarajevo. Early in the morning on that day he was on a meeting with Serbian, Croatian and Slovenian students in honour of the Serbian national day – Vidovdan. On the same evening a ball was organised for the same reason, but due to the evolving political and diplomatic situation it was cancelled. As a Serbian student and member of the Serbian Students' Association "Zora", Crnjanski was, as the others, suspicious in the eyes of the Viennese police. Shortly after that, Crnjanski moved to Novi Sad, and later he was arrested and mobilised in the Austro-Hungarian Army. After the First World War (1914-1918) he moved to Belgrade, where he studied literature and worked as a teacher and newspaper editor (of the newspaper "Ideje"). From 1935 Miloš Crnjanski was in the diplomatic service of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia in Rome and Berlin. Together with the government he escaped from the German invasion of Yugoslavia in April 1941 to London via Lisbon. In London he continued his diplomatic activities as a member of a recognised Allied country. After the Second World War (1939-1945) he stayed in London in exile as an enemy of the newly established Communist regime in Socialist Yugoslavia. He returned to Belgrade from exile twenty years later, in 1965, where he died in 1977. His most famous book was "Seobe" ("Migrations"), which describes the life of the Serbs in the Austrian Empire in the 18th century.

depictions.title: Franz Theodor Maria Csokor (1885-1969)
Tomb of Franz Theodor Csokor

description.value: Franz Theodor Maria Csokor (1885-1969) was born on 6 September 1885 in Linke Bahngasse 7 (1030 Vienna) and was baptised on 13 September 1885 in the Roman Catholic church of St. Rochus (Landstraßer Hauptstraße 54, 1030 Vienna). He was a famous Austrian writer, poet and dramatic advisor of Serbian origin. His father was Jovan Čokor (1849-1911), Professor at the University of Vienna. After studying History of Art and German Philology at the University of Vienna, he wrote his first works between 1912 and 1918 (e.g. "Die Gewalten", "Die Sünde wider den Geist’", "Die rote Straße" etc). From 1922 to 1928 he was a dramatic advisor at the Raimundtheater and the Volkstheater in Vienna, and later he became President of the Austrian PEN Club. From 1968 he was Vice-President of International PEN Club. Csokor received amongst others the Literarurpreis der Stadt Wien in 1927, the Burgtheaterring in 1938, the Grillparzer Preis in 1938 and the Großer Österreichischer Staatspreis in 1955. Since 1933 he had risen his voice against the persecution of writers in Germany, which led to a ban of his books there. It is interesting that Csokor, who was a great humanist and enemy of National Socialism, was in exile since 1938 and that he lived in Yugoslavia, the country of his ancestors, from 1941 to 1944. He described this period in his autobiographic work "Als Zivilist im Balkankrieg" (Vienna 1947). However, his most popular work was "3 November 1918", which was staged in the Burgtheater in Vienna. Franz Theodor Maria Csokor died on 5 January 1969 in the Franz Josefs Spital in Vienna and was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).

depictions.title: Konstantin Cukić (1826-1879)

description.value: Konstantin Cukić (1826-1879) studied at a grammar school in Vienna from 1838 and then at the University of Heidelberg from 1843, where he was promoted to Dr. of Philosophy. Konstantin Cukić was Minister of Finance and Education in Serbia, Senator, Member of the Serbian Learned Society ("Srpsko Učeno Društvo") and the first Serbian diplomat in Vienna from 1874. He was decorated with the Order of the Serbian Takovo Cross and also with the Austrian Order of Leopold. Cukić died in his apartment in Frankenberggasse 5 (1040 Vienna) on 17 March 1879. His remains were transferred to Belgrade, where he was buried.

description.value: Aleksandar Cvejić (1832-1911), an Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman, was born in Mohol (today Serbia) on 1 April 1832. He took part in several wars and battles, including those of Melegnano and Solferino (both 1859). Aleksandar Cvejić was honored with the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class and became an Austrian nobleman (Knight) with the title "von Potissje" in 1860. Aleksandar Cvejić was also honored with the Knight's Cross of the Order of Leopold ("Ritterkreuz des Leopold Ordens") in 1887), the War Medal, the Military Merit Medal and the Military Merit Cross with War decoration. He was a honorary citizen of Stolac (today Herzegovina). After his retirement in 1887 Aleksandar Cvejić settled in Vienna, where he was one of the donators for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in 1891. He died in Straußengasse 15 (1050 Vienna) at the age of 79 on 29 March 1911. After a memorial service in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava he was buried in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) three days later.

depictions.title: Jovan Cvijić (1865-1927)

description.value:
Jovan Cvijić (1865-1927) is the best-known Serbian geologist and geographer. He was born on 12 October 1865 in Loznica (Serbia). After attending grammar school in Loznica and Šabac, he studied Natural Sciences and Mathematics at the Faculty of the High School in Belgrade from 1885 to 1888. After completing his studies, he began his systematic field trips through the Balkan Peninsula for the next 38 years. Jovan Cvijić researched more than 500,000 square kilometers of territory. In autumn 1889 he came to Vienna as a scholarship holder. He attended lectures on Physical Geography and Cartography. On 22 January 1893 he was promoted to Dr. His PhD was entitled "Das Karstphänomen" ("The Karst Phenomenon"). For the first time this work was printed in Vienna in the autumn of the same year. Great influence on the young Jovan Cvijić had his professors at the University of Vienna (i.e. Eduard Suess, Albrecht Penck, Julius Hann and Wilhelm Tomascheck). He often had meetings with Professor Albrecht Penck (1858-1945), where the topic of conversation was the geography of the Balkan Peninsula. His dissertation is still considered to be a fundamental work in the field of Karstology. Jovan Cvijić was the leading Karstologist of his generation, and probably the greatest Karstologist of the 19th and early 20th centuries. He has often been called the "Father of Karst Studies". 
It is also important to say that Jovan Cvijić introduced several Serbian words to the scientific terminology, like Polje, Dolina, Uvala. From 1893 until his death in 1927 he was a Professor, first at the High School in Belgrade, and from 1905 (after the conversion of the High School in Belgrade to the University of Belgrade on 27 February 1905) full Professor of the University of Belgrade. He was also twice Rector of the University of Belgrade (1907/08 and 1919/20) and President of the Serbian Royal Academy (today Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts) from 1921 to 1927. 
Jovan Cvijić was the founder of the Serbian Geographical Society ("Srpsko geografsko društvo", 1910) and the journal of the Serbian Geographical Society ("Glasnik Srpskog geografskog društva", 1912), which is still published today. In addition to his fundamental works on Geomorphology, Geography and Geology his anthropological and ethnographic publications are outstanding. He was the founder of the Serbian settlement research. 
Jovan Cvijić played an eminent role in the Paris Peace Conference after the First World War (1919/20). He was the head of the Serbian ethnographic-historical department (in this delegation were, amongst others, the Serbian historians and former Viennese students Tihomir Djordjević, Jovan Radonić and StanojeStanojević). This department had collected scholarly, statistical and cartographic data for the negotiations. 
In 1897 Jovan Cvijić published his map of Serbia and Montenegro in Vienna, which was used in the schools. The map is printed on a scale of 1: 750,000, and in the left corner one can find the map of Belgrade on a scale 1: 75,000. This map symbolises a great advancement in Serbian cartography and marked the beginning of a new era in Serbian cartography. 

Jovan Cvijić was a honorary doctor of the Sorbonne University and the Charles University in Prague and a member of all major geographical societies in Europe at that time (Vienna, Paris, London, Prague, Budapest, Warsaw, Berlin etc.). He received several scientific prizes in the field of Geography. Jovan Cvijić died on 16 January 1927 in Belgrade.

depictions.title: Djura Daničić (1825-1882)

description.value: Djura Daničić (1825-1882) was a Serbian philologist, translator and linguistic historian. He was born in Novi Sad on 4 April 1825 as Djordje Popović. After attending the grammar school in Bratislava, he came to Vienna in order to study Law in 1845. He had already been a supporter of Vuk Karadžić's ideas, and in Vienna he became one of Vuk's most important associates. In Vuk's house he became acquainted with the Bishop Petar II Petrović Njegoš of Montenegro, Ljuba Nenadović, Danilo Medaković, Prince Mihailo Obrenović, Prince Miloš Obrenović, Anastas Jovanović and many others. His best friend in Vienna was the Serbian poet Branko Radičević. Already in 1846 he gave up his studies in Law and turned to Philology. His professor was Franz von Miklosich. Djura Daničić spoke Latin, German, Hungarian, Polish, Czech, Slovak and Russian, before he moved to Vienna. As Vuk's most dedicated follower he printed brochures, in which he supported Vuk's ideas. His most important text was "The War for the Serbian Language and Orthography" ("Рат за Српски језик и правопис") printed in Pest in 1847. He signed this publication as Djura Daničić. He took his new last name after Vuk's journal "Danica". Since 1849 he lived in Landstraße 487 (today Beatrixgasse 12, 1030 Vienna). He helped Vuk in the new edition of his "Dictionary" ("Рјечник") and in 1852 he moved to Belgrade. After only one year (in 1853) he returned to Vienna on the invitation of Prince Mihailo Obrenović in order to teach the Serbian Princess Julija. For three years Djura Daničić was the teacher of the Princess, and she became his benefactor, financially supporting the printing of his books. In 1860 he translated the Old Testament into Serbian. It is interesting to mention that he taught Serbian also to Princess Natalija Obrenović in Paris in 1876. In Vienna he printed his "Small Serbian Grammar" ("Мала српска граматика", 1850) and "New Serbian Spelling Grammar" ("Нови српски буквар", 1854). Djura Daničić settled in Belgrade in 1856 as a grammar school teacher and in 1866 he moved to Zagreb, where he died on 17 November 1882.

depictions.title: Josif Danilovac (1877-1945), Painting
Josif Danilovac (1877-1945), Serbian Priests (1926)

description.value: Josif Danilovac (1877-1945) was a famous Viennese painter, lithograph and caricaturist of Serbian origin. He was born in Althanstraße 7-9 (1090 Vienna) as a son of a Serbian barber on 22 November 1877. Josif Danilovac studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") from 1896. From 1908 he worked as a caricaturist in the newspaper "Die Muskete". Josif Danilovac signed a contract with the model railway company "Märklin", for which he drew catalogues until 1940. He married Maria Lasus in 1913, and they had a son called Marko and a daughter called Angelina. After 1938 he was banned from his work in the newspapers, because of his critique of the Nazi regime and because his wife was of Jewish origin. He died in his apartment in Gymnasiumstraße 29 (1180 Vienna) on 20 November 1945, where he lived since 1940. Josif Danilovac was buried after a memorial service in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna in a grave of honor at the Cemetery of Döbling. The Council Committee for Culture ("Gemeinderatsausschuß für Kultur") of the City of Vienna named a street, Danilovatzgasse, in the 12th and 23rd Viennese districts after him on 8 June 1955.

description.value: Toma Danilović (1871-1905) was a Serbian merchant and owner of a restaurant in Vienna, who was born in Serbia in 1871. He was the owner of the famous Viennese restaurant "Zum weißen Wolf" (Wolfengasse 3, 1010 Vienna) in 1897. He died in his apartment in Dominikanerbastei 21 (1010 Vienna) on 26 May 1905.

Quite often the opinion emerges in the contemporary public discourse that the Orthodox Christians have come to Austria for the first time in the wake of the so-called "Gastarbeiterbewegung" of the 1960s and 1970s. However, their history and presence in Austria dates well back to the 17th century. In fact, according to the Austro-Hungarian population census of 1910, more than 2,000,000 Serbs lived in the Habsburg monarchy: in Hungary a total of 1,106,471, in Bosnia and Herzegovina 825,338 and in Dalmatia 105,000.
This research project uses biographical data on the Orthodox Serbs in Vienna in the period from 1741 until 1918 in order to illustrate how the Orthodox began to migrate to the Habsburg Empire, how Orthodox merchants settled in Vienna and how they integrated into Viennese society of that time. On the basis of meticulously researched data in Austrian archives the life of famous Serbs in Vienna is reconstructed. Their places of dwelling and action are localised and embedded into a customised OpenAtlas database with an online Geoportal, which will be open to the interested public at the end of the project.
This project aims to gain a better understanding of contemporary developments and future trends in Orthodox Christianity based on scholarly research on famous Serbian personalities of the 18th and 19th centuries in detail, which were already integrated into Austrian society at that time in Vienna as well as in Austria in general.
types.label: A Digital Geoportal of the History of the Serbs in Vienna 1741-1918

depictions.title: Dimitrije Davidović (1789-1838)
Novine Serbske No 1 (Vienna 1813)
Serbian Constitution (1835)
Zabavnik of Dimitrije Davidović (1815)

description.value:
Dimitrije Davidović (1789-1838) was a journalist, publisher and writer in Vienna from 1812 to 1821. After his return to Serbia he was the secretary of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860), Minister of Education and diplomat. In 1835 he was the creator of the first Serbian constitution. He was also a publisher and editor of the "Novine Srbske" in Serbia in the years 1834/1835.
Davidović's father, Gavrilo Georgijević, was an Orthodox priest in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George in Vienna. Dimitrije Davidović took his last name after his grandfather, David Georgijević, who was a teacher and Orthodox priest in Zemun and in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia). Davidović came to Vienna together with Dimitrije Frušić (1790-1838) in autumn 1812. They were both students of Medicine. Supported by Jernej Kopitar (1780-1844), the imperial censor for Slavic languages, they started to publish the Serbian newspaper "Novine serbske" in 1813. Davidović and Frušić were the owners, editors and publishers of this newspaper, which was published until February 1822. During the Congress of Vienna ("Wiener Kongreß") in 1814 they helped the former Serbian Minister Matija Nenadović substantially to inform the Great European Powers on the Serbian question. From 1818 to 1822 Davidović had his own printing house in Fleischmarkt 746 (1010 Vienna). On 1 October 1818 he received a privilege for printing books in Oriental languages. He left Vienna in autumn 1821 and the editor's position to his co-worker, Petar Matić, a law student from Zemun. He married Jelisaveta-Savka Diamandi on 30 May 1817 in Pest. They lived in the house Innere Stadt 699 (1010 Vienna). Jelisaveta died during childbirth on 23 May 1818 in this house at the age of 35. She was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 25 May 1818. Their son was named Svetozar (he died in Vienna in the 1850s). Dimitrije Davidović married one year later his second wife, Jelena, on 26 January 1819. They had the sons Milan, Jovan (born in Vienna in 1820) and a daughter Savka (born in Serbia about 1828 and died 1841). Dimitrije Davidović published in Vienna his two books "Sobranie nauka svakomu čoveku nuždni" (1814) and "Dejanija k istoriji Srbskoga naroda" (1821).

depictions.title: Totenbeschaubefund des Georgi Delaga vom 5. Februar 1917 (Copyright Metropolis von Austria)

description.value: Georgi Delaga wurde 1883 in Herodnik geboren. Er war Landwirt. Georgi Delaga litt an Lungentuberkulose und starb am 5. Februar 1917 im Spital des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn an einem Lungenödem. Er wurde am 5. Februar 1917 beschaut und sollte am 7. Februar 1917 beerdigt werden. ------------ Georgi Delaga was born in Herodnik in 1883. He was a farmer. Georgi Delaga suffered from pulmonary tuberculosis and died of pulmonary oedema on the 5th of February 1917 in the hospital of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn. He was examined on the 5th of February 1917 and was to be buried on the 7th of February 1917.

depictions.title: Totenbeschaubefund der Julia Demediuk vom 18. Februar 1917 (Copyright Metropolis von Austria)

description.value: Julia Demediuk wurde am 23. Dezember 1916 in Flüchtlingslager Oberhollabrunn geboren. Sie war die Tochter einer Tagelöhnerin. Julia Demediuk litt an einer angeborenen Lebensschwäche und starb am 18. Februar 1917 im Flüchtlingslager Oberhollabunn an einer Herzlähmung. Sie wurde am 18. Februar 1917 beschaut und sollte am 20. Februar 1917 beerdigt werden. ----------- Julia Demediuk was born on the 23rd of December 1916 in the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn. She was the daughter of a day labourer. Julia Demediuk suffered from a congenital life weakness and died of heart paralysis in the refugee camp Oberhollabunn on the 18th of February 1917. She was examined on the 18th of February 1917 and was to be buried on the 20th of February 1917.

depictions.title: Totenbeschaubefund der Demeter vom 17. März 1918 (Copyright Metropolis von Austria)

description.value: Demeter war das uneheliche Kind von der Landwirtin Anna Andrejezuk. Demeter wurde am 17. März 1918 im Flüchtlingslager Oberhollabrunn geboren und verstarb noch am selben Tag. Sie litt an einer angeborenen Lebensschwäche. ------------- Demeter was the illegitimate child of the farmer Anna Andrejezuk. Demeter was born on the 17th of March 1918 in the Oberhollabrunn refugee camp and died the same day. She suffered from a congenital life weakness.

description.value: Konstantin von Despinić (1839-1906) was one of the owners of the Viennese Company "B.Despinits & Comp." since 27 December 1862, which traded with diverse products, especially with meat. At that time he still lived in Kovin (Military Frontier, today Serbia). The other owners were his brothers Vasilije von Despinić, merchant from Vienna, and Jovan von Despinić as well as Aleksandar Marković from Kovin. The address of the company was Landstraßer Hauptstraße 43 (1030 Vienna). In 1888 Vasilije and Jovan were deleted from the commercial register, because they had died. At the same time Aron and Pavle von Despinić from Kovin were registered as owners. From 7 November 1879 Konstantin von Despinić was the owner of the Company "C. Despinits" in Simmeringer Hauptstrasse 16 (1110 Vienna). On 29 April 1898 the company was deleted from the commercial register. Konstantin von Despinić was a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava during the time of the building of the church in the 1880s/90s and then President of the respective council from 1885 until 1888.

depictions.title: Vladan Djordjević (1844-1930)

description.value: Vladan Djordjević (1844-1930) was a Serbian physician, politician and writer, who was born in Belgrade on 3 December 1844. In 1863 he received a scholarship by the Serbian government in order to study Medicine at the University of Vienna. His first apartment was in Wieden (1040 Vienna), and he attended lectures at the Theresianum. His professors were renowned experts in medicine: Josef von Škoda (1805-1881), Theodor Billroth (1829-1894) and Joseph Hyrtl (1810-1894). During his studies he regularly attended performances in the Burgtheater. Vladan Djordjević graduated in 1869 and in the same year he became Doctor of Medicine and Surgery. During his studies in Vienna he met his future wife Pauline Bitner. They married in Belgrade in 1871. In 1870 he became a member of the Society of Physicians in Vienna ("Gesellschaft der Ärzte in Wien"). Djordjević was the founder of the Serbian Physicians' Society ("Srpsko Lekarsko Društvo") in 1872 and of the Serbian Red Cross in 1876. Then Vladan Djordjević started a political career. He was mayor of Belgrade (1884-1888), Minister of Education (1888-1889), ambassador in Athens (1891-1893) and Constantinople (1894-1897) and Prime Minister (1897-1900). In 1888 he became a corresponding member of the Serbian Royal Academy and four years later (1892) a full member. After a conflict with the Serbian King Aleksandar Obrenović (1876-1903), Djordjević moved to Vienna in 1900, where he wrote his memoirs and articles for different Viennese newspapers (e.g. the Neue Freie Presse, Wiener Tagblatt, Wiener Abendblatt, etc.). He returned to Belgrade in 1905. In 1920 Vladan Djordjević returned to Vienna, where he lived in a rented apartment in Rienößlgasse 24 (1040 Vienna) until 1924. He collected sources from Viennese archives for his books. Because of illness he had to stay in different Viennese Sanatoria. In 1930 Djordjević moved to a Sanatorium in Baden, where he died on 31 August 1930.

description.value: Avram Djukić (1844-1906) was a retired "Generalintendant" of the Austro-Hungarian Army and a historian. He was decorated with of the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class, the Order of Franz Joseph, the War Medal, etc. He died on 30 March 1906 in his apartment in Dreilaufergasse 6 (today Lindengasse 6, 1070 Vienna). Avram Djukić was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) after the memorial service in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna.

depictions.title: Tomb of Vasilije Djurdjević

description.value: Vaso Djurdjević (1841-1915) was born in Osijek (today Croatia) on 20 September 1841. He was a journalist, lawyer and politician. From 1875 to 1906 Dr. Vaso Djurdjević was a member of the Croatian and from 1878 to 1906 of the Hungarian Parliament. From 1884 to 1893 he was Vice-President and from 1893 to 1906 President of Croatian Parliament. In 1897 Djurdjević was awarded with the Komtur Cross with star of the Franz Josef Order. He died in Untere Weißgerberstraße 61 (1030 Vienna) on 26 December 1915 and was buried in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).

depictions.title: Coat of Arms of the Family Djurković

description.value:
Djordje Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota (1843-1908) was a journalist, a member of the Hungarian and Croatian Parliaments, a member of the Serbian National Congress and a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna. Since 1876 Djurković was an editor and journalist in the Viennese newspaper "Die Presse". He died in Budapest on 25 May 1908, where he was editor of the newspaper "Neues Pester Journal". 
He published the following works in Vienna:
- Die Schauspielschule des Wiener Conservatoriums 1874-1876 (F. Beck, Wien 1876)
- Eine Studie über Lessing's Laokoon (Rosner, Wien 1876)
- Bosnien und die Nebenländer: Schilderungen von Land und Leuten zwischen der Donau und der Adria (Hölder, Wien 1879)
- Albanien. Schilderungen von Land und Leute. Mit 3 Illustrationen (Hölder, Wien 1881)

description.value: Maks Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota was a civil servant and the son of Djordje Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota (1843-1908). He was born in Vienna in 1864 and studied Law at the University of Vienna between 1884 and 1888. He received the title of "Hofrat" in 1911 and was honored with the title of "Sektionschef" in May 1914. He was deputy chief of the provincial government ("Landesregierung") in Bosnia and Herzegovina since 1917. Djurković married Angelina Stefanija Andjelić in Budapest on 20 March 1898. Persida, their daughter, was born on 6 March 1899 and baptised in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 1 May 1899. Djurković was awarded with the Commander's Cross ("Komturkreuz") 1st Class of the Saxon Albrecht Order in 1915. Djurković was honored with the title of "Geheimrat" in December 1917. Furthermore, he received the Order of the Iron Crown 2nd class in 1916. He was awarded the "Kriegskreuz für Zivilverdienste" 1st class in 1917. Djurković wrote for the newspaper "Die Presse" and translated the novel of the Serbian writer Laza Lazarević (1851-1891) entitled "Prvi put s ocem na jutrenje" ("Mein erster Gang zur Frühmesse") in "Die Presse" (25 August 1892).

description.value: Philipp Dragicz wurde im Jahr 1862 in der Ortschaft Keschwana (Cajvana, Rumänien) geboren. Er war Landwirt. Philipp Dragicz litt an einer Nierenentzündung und starb schließlich am 20. Juni 1918 im Spital des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn an einer Harnröhrenstriktur. Am 20. Juni 1918 wurde er beschaut und er sollte am 22. Juni 1918 beerdigt werden. -----------Philipp Dragicz was born in 1862 in the village of Keschwana (Cajvana, Romania). He was a farmer. Philipp Dragicz suffered from nephritis and finally died of a urethral stricture on the 20th of June 1918 in the hospital of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn. He was examined on the 20th of June 1918 and was to be buried on the 22th of June 1918.

depictions.title: Family Tomb of Budislav von Drndarski

description.value:
Budislav Edler von Drndarski (1873-1936) was an official and a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in Vienna. He was Vice-President of the Community Council. Budislav Drndadrski was born in Wadowice (today Poland) on 30 March 1873. He married Helene Kietzl  in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 11 February 1901. Budislav Drndadrski lived at this time in St. Pölten (Neugasse 8). 
They had five children: Danica was born on 30 November 1901 in Sankt Pölten and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 1 March 1902.  Dušan was born on 25 January 1903 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 19 March 1903. Uroš was born on 10 September 1906 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 28 November. Zorka was born on 1 July 1908 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 27 August. Vera was born on 10 March 1911 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 17 April. Zorka's and Vera's godmother was Jelena Ostojić (1874-1967).
Budislav Drndarski was promoted to Ministerial Vice-Secretary in 1906 and then to Ministerial Secretary in the Ministry of Finance in 1910. His father, Lieutenant colonel Velizar Drndarski, was ennobled in 1900. Budislav Drndarski died in the City's Hospital (1130 Vienna) on 28 June 1936 and was buried three days later. In his family tomb in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) are buried also his mother Sofija (1845-1908) and his children Zora (died in 1908) and Uroš (died in 1907). His wife Helene (né Kietzl in St. Pölten on 5 June 1875) died in their family apartment in Lainzerstraße 124 (1130 Vienna) on 23 October 1936 and was also buried in the tomb next to her husband three days later.

types.description:
This research project focuses on one of the aspects of the history and presence of Orthodox Christians, and in particular of the Orthodox Serbs, in Vienna. Quite often the opinion emerges in the contemporary public discourse that the Orthodox Christians have come to Austria for the first time in the wake of the so-called "Gastarbeiterbewegung" of the 1960s and 1970s. However, their history and presence in Austria dates well back to the 17th century. In fact, according to the Austro-Hungarian population census of 1910, more than 2,000,000 Serbs lived in the Habsburg monarchy: in Hungary a total of 1,106,471, in Bosnia and Herzegovina 825,338 and in Dalmatia 105,000.
This research project uses biographical data on the Orthodox Serbs in Vienna in the period from 1741 until 1918 in order to illustrate how the Orthodox began to migrate to the Habsburg Empire, how Orthodox merchants settled in Vienna and how they integrated into Viennese society of that time. On the basis of meticulously researched data in Austrian archives the life of famous Serbs in Vienna is reconstructed. Their places of dwelling and action are localised and embedded into a customised OpenAtlas database with an online Geoportal, which will be open to the interested public at the end of the project.
This project aims to gain a better understanding of contemporary developments and future trends in Orthodox Christianity based on scholarly research on famous Serbian personalities of the 18th and 19th centuries in detail, which were already integrated into Austrian society at that time in Vienna as well as in Austria in general.
types.label: A Digital Geoportal of the History of the Serbs in Vienna 1741-1918

depictions.title: Coat of Arms of Petar Duka de Kadar
Petar Duka de Kadar (1756-1822)

description.value: Petar Duka de Kadar (1756-1822) was a General of the Artillery ("Feldzeugmeister"), commanding General in the region of Banat, nobleman ("Baron"), "k. k.Geheimer Rat" and Knight of the Military Order of Maria Theresia. He was born in Osijek (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in a merchant's family of Serbian origin in 1756. Duka began a very long military career in 1776. After the victorious Battle of Famars (1793) against the French Revolutionary Army he became Knight of the Maria Theresia Order. In 1800 Duka was promoted to Major General. He became commander of the fortress in Timișoara (today Romania) and in 1813 General of the Artillery ("Feldzeugsmeister"). In 1815 Duka was honored with the title of "k. k. Geheimer Rat" by the Austrian Emperor Franz I (1768-1835). The Infantry Regiment No. 39 carried his name since 1803. Apart from the Large Cross of the Leopold Order he was also the holder of many Russian, Prussian, Bavarian, French and Sicilian decorations. Duka received Hungarian nobility with the rank of "Baron" and became the owner of the landed property Kadar in Banat (today Romania). Therefore, his title was "de Kadar" or "von Kadar". From 1815 he was a member of the State Council ("Staatsrat") and because of that he settled in Vienna. Petar Duka de Kadar died on 29 December 1822 in the house in Renngasse 10 (1010 Vienna). He was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) and in 1907 his mortal remains were exhumed and buried in Kadar.

description.value: Emilie Friedrich (1831-1892) was the daughter of the famous Viennese sculptor Dimitrije Petrović ( (1799-1854) and the sister of the painter Ladislav Eugen Petrović (1839-1907). She was born in Vienna on 29 May 1831 and was a professional dancer at the "Theater an der Wien" (1849-1851), the "Hofoper" (April-June 1851) and from 1852 at the "Carltheater" in Vienna and also in Bucharest. Emilie Friedrich died in Orșova (today Romania) on 28 May 1892.

depictions.title: Dimitrije Frušić with His Family

description.value: Dimitrije Frušić (1790-1838) was born in 1790 in Divoš (today Serbia). He came to Vienna in autmn 1812 together with Dimitrije Davidović in order to study Medicine. Together they founded as editors and owners the "Novine Serbske" and published them from 1813 to 1816. In 1816, after he had finished his studies, he moved to Trieste, where he worked as a doctor and died in 1838.

depictions.title: Milutin Garašanin (1843-1898)

description.value: Milutin Garašanin (1843-1898) was the son of the famous Serbian politician Ilija Garašanin (1812-1874). He studied at the Artillery School in Metz (France) and after that he participated in the Serbian-Turkish Wars 1876-1878. Garašanin ended his military career in the rank of colonel. In 1881 he was one of the founders and the first President of the Serbian Progressive Party ("Srpska Napredna Stranka"). He was Prime Minister from 1884 to 1886 and twice Minister of Internal Affairs. Garašanin edited the newspapers "Videlo" and "Pogled". He was a member of the Serbian Royal Academy and Serbian ambassador in Vienna from 1883 to 1884 as well as in Paris.

description.value: Аndrija Gerlović was а Viennese merchant of Slavonic origin, houseowner and the owner of a café. He was partner in the Company "Klaar et Gerlovich" (Am Hof No. 323 "zum weißen Hasen"). Аndrija Gerlović was the owner of the so-called "Slavonic Café" (also "Café Gerlovich") in Bauernmarkt 5 (1010 Vienna, does not exist anymore). Many prominent Viennese Slavs and among them many Serbes (e.g. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić, Djura Daničić etc.) were his guests in the 1840s.

depictions.title: Spiridon Gopčević Jr. (1855-1936?)

description.value: Spiridon Gopčević Jr. (1855-1936?) was a Serbian diplomat, journalist and astronomer born in Trieste in 1855. His father was Spiridon Gopčević Sr. (1809-1861), one of the richest Serbs in the Habsburg Empire. After his father's death in 1861, the young Spiridon lived in Vienna with his mother and his sister. After attending St. Anna Jesuit school he studied at the grammar school in Melk until 1869. In 1874 and 1875 he was at the Viennese Conservatorium. Here Gopčević had financial support from General Djordje Stratimirović (1822-1908), whom Gopčević's father had helped during the Revolution of 1848 in the battle against the Hungarians. In 1875 Spiridon Gopčević Jr. took part in Montenegrin uprising against the Turks, and later he became correspondent of many Austrian newspapers. Gopčecić wrote many books and pamphlets on the history, ethnology and politics in the Balkan Peninsula. From 1886 to 1887 he was the Serbian attaché in Berlin and from 1887 to 1890 in Vienna. In 1886 he married Franziska Praskowitz in Vienna. Their son Spiridon was born in Trieste in 1883 and their daughter Danica in Vienna in 1888. Spiridon Gopčević Jr. was the owner and editor of the Viennese newspaper "Wiener Tagespost" from May 1890 until January 1891. He corresponded with many European artists and statesmen, amongst others with Otto von Bismarck (1815-1898), Giuseppe Garibaldi (1807-1882), William Ewart Gladstone (1809-1898) and Victor Hugo (1802-1885). In 1891 he left Vienna and moved to Celje (today Slovenia) and then in 1893 to the island of Mali Lošinj (today Croatia). There he founded the observatory named "Manora" and published many works in the field of Astronomy under the pseudonym Leo Brenner. Spiridon Gopčević Jr. stayed there until 1908 and published the a journal on Astronomy called "Astronomische Rundschau", which was issued monthly from 1899 to 1908. He travelled through the USA, Siberia, the Middle East and North Africa. From ca. 1909 to 1912 he lived in the USA and later moved to Berlin, where he stayed until the end of his life. The date of his death is unknown. The most common years which are mentioned in encyclopaedias are 1928 and 1936.

depictions.title: Tomb of Spiridon Gopčević Sr.

description.value:
Spiridon Gopčević Sr. (1809-1861) was a Serbian merchant and shipowner from Trieste, who came to Vienna in 1858. He was Knight of the Franz Josef Order (1854) and was also decorated with the Russian Imperial Gold Medal of Honour. He was married to Louise Gopčević (born Ehmann), and they had two children Spiridon (Gopčević Jr.) and Olga. Gopčević owned several ships and named some of them after Serbian rulers, for example "Car Lazar" (1842) and "Fürst Karadjordjević". "Fürst Karadjordjević" was built in England in 1851 with a weight of 57 tons and was the first private steamship in the Habsburg Empire. After the Crimean War (1853-1856) he lost almost all of his property and fell ill. Spiridon Gopčević Sr. committed suicide on 8 May 1861 in Landstraßer Hauptstraße 99 and was buried on 11 May 1861 in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). 
After his death his wife Louise married Josef Brix. She died in the house in Lerchenfelderstraße 39 (1070 Vienna) at the age of 39 on 24 December 1872. She was buried in the Matzleinsdorf Cemetery on 26 December 1872.

In fact, according to the Austro-Hungarian population census of 1910, more than 2,000,000 Serbs lived in the Habsburg monarchy: in Hungary a total of 1,106,471, in Bosnia and Herzegovina 825,338 and in Dalmatia 105,000.
This research project uses biographical data on the Orthodox Serbs in Vienna in the period from 1741 until 1918 in order to illustrate how the Orthodox began to migrate to the Habsburg Empire, how Orthodox merchants settled in Vienna and how they integrated into Viennese society of that time. On the basis of meticulously researched data in Austrian archives the life of famous Serbs in Vienna is reconstructed. Their places of dwelling and action are localised and embedded into a customised OpenAtlas database with an online Geoportal, which will be open to the interested public at the end of the project.
This project aims to gain a better understanding of contemporary developments and future trends in Orthodox Christianity based on scholarly research on famous Serbian personalities of the 18th and 19th centuries in detail, which were already integrated into Austrian society at that time in Vienna as well as in Austria in general.

description.value: Eveline von Goutta (né Aleksić von Maina) (1824-1899) was the daughter of the Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman Jovan Aleksić von Maina (1783-1861). She married Field marshal-lieutenant Franz Ritter von Goutta (1828-1908) in Vienna on 24 April 1858. She lived in Seilerstätte 28 (1010 Vienna). Eveline von Goutta died on 1 May 1899 at the age of 75 in Leonhardgasse 3-5 (in the "Nervenheilanstalt Svetlin", 1030 Vienna) and was buried two days later in the Hietzing Cemetery (Hietzinger Friedhof, 1130 Vienna).

depictions.title: Branko (Filaret) Granić (1883-1948)

description.value: Branko (Filaret) Granić (1883-1948) was a Serbian historian, theologian, Professor at University and monk (Filaret). He was born in Kikinda (today Serbia) on 13 September 1883. After attending grammar school in Novi Sad, he studied Philosophy in Vienna (1901-1903) and Munich, where he received his PhD. After returning from Germany, he became a monk with the name Filaret. From 1926 Branko (Filaret) Granić was Professor of Byzantine Studies at the University of Skoplje (today Republic of North Macedonia). Later Granić moved to Belgrade, where he was Professor of Theology and Byzantine Studies. He became a corresponding member of the Serbian Royal Academy in 1935 and a full member in 1940. Branko (Filaret) Granić died in Belgrade on 3 February 1948.

depictions.title: Radoslav Grba (1849-1918)

description.value: Radoslav Grba (1849-1918) was a General of Infantry in the Habsburg Empire. He was born in Ogulin (Military Frontier, today Croatia) on 1 May 1849. From 1885 to 1886 he worked in the War Archive ("Kriegsarchiv") in Vienna. Since 1909 he was General of Infantry and from 1913 Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat"). In the year 1910 the Infantry Regiment No. 78 carried Grba's name. Radoslav Grba was decorated with the Knight's Cross of the Order of Leopold, the Order of the Iron Crown 1st class and the Grand Cross of the Franz Josef Order. He died in Opatija (today Croatia). Until his death his Viennese apartment was in Alleegasse 53 (today Argentinierstraße 53, 1040 Vienna).

He was examined on the 18th of June 1917 and he was to be buried on the 20th of June 1917.

depictions.title: Filip Hristić (1819-1905)

description.value: Filip Hristić (1819-1905) studied Law at the Sorbonne University in Paris, where he received his PhD in 1848. Before that he was in Vienna from 1839 to 1842, where he learned German and French and began to study Philosophy. In Vienna Filip Hristić lived first in the guesthouse "Zum Weißen Wolf" (Wolfengasse1, 1010 Vienna) and then in Annagasse. In 1858 he became the secretary of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). Later he was Prime Minister (1860-1861), Minister of Education and Minister of Foreign Affairs. As a diplomat he was Serbian Ambassador in  London, Constantinople and Vienna (from December 1879 to the end of 1882). In 1885 Filip Hristić was appointed to Governor of the Serbian National Bank. Since 1892 he was a honorary member of the Serbian Royal Academy.

depictions.title: Kosta Hristić (1852-1927)

description.value: Kosta Hristić (1852-1927) studied Law in Germany and France. He began his diplomatic career as a secretary of the Serbian Legation in Constantinople in 1883. Later he was promoted to Consul General in Thessaloniki and chief of a section in the Serbian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Hristić was also Minister of Justice from 1897 to 1899). He was Serbian ambassador in Bucharest, Rome and Vienna. His Viennese appointment was between 1900 and 1903, and in his memoirs he left a very important and vivid testimony of this period, especially of his relation to King Milan Obrenović (1854-1901) and Princess Julie (1831-1919).

depictions.title: Tomb of the Family Ilić in the Viennese Central Cemetery 01
Tomb of the Family Ilić in the Viennese Central Cemetery 02

description.value: Aleksandar Ilić (1860-1943) was a Viennese sculptor born on 23 May 1860 in Hundsturm 116 (1050 Vienna). He was baptised on 27 May 1860 in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt (1010 Vienna). His father was the Viennese jeweller and inventor Mihailo Ilić. Aleksandar Ilić studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") from 1879 to 1880 and from 1884 to 1890. Already during his studies, Aleksandar Ilić received a scholarship and awards. He had the "Rechenberg Stipendium" (75 florins) in 1882/83, received support by the "Aushilfsfond" (120 florins) in 1883/4 and had the "Franz Joseph Goldenes Stipendium" (300 florins) from 1885 to 1888. In 1890 he received a scholarship called "Schwendenwein Reisestipendium" and travelled to Italy (Rome) and Germany until 1892. Aleksandar Ilić was awarded the "Füger-Preis" in silver in 1883, the "Gundel-Preis" in silver in 1884 and the "Spezialschul-Preis" in 1888. His works in Vienna are to be found for example in the Donaufelderkirche (1210 Vienna) dating to 1909 (Busts of Capistran, Floridus and Koloman, the Family Altar, reliefs of the Passion of Christ and relief in the Baptism Chapel). From 1901 to 1903 Aleksandar Ilić made sandstone statues for the municipal office in Florisdorf. On 29 December 1899 he became a member of the "Künstlerhaus". In 1909 he was awarded the "Dumba Art Prize" ("Dumba-Künstlerpreis") for his work "Es ist vollbracht!". He lived from 1914 until his death in Peter-Jordan-Straße 100 (1190 Vienna). Aleksandar Ilić died on 8 January 1943 in Vienna and was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) in the family tomb next to his father.
