description.value: Svetozar Teodorović de Szent-Endre (1822-1907) was born in Pomáz (near Budapest, today Hungary) on 5 September 1822. He married Sofija Pejčić on 18 October 1869. Svetozar Teodorović de Szent-Endre received the Knight's Cross of the Franz Josef Order in 1869, the Officer's Cross of the Italian Mauritius and Lazarus Order in 1875  and the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class on 9 July 1882. He started his career as diplomat in 1847. Svetozar Teodorović de Szent-Endre served in Belgrade, Sarajevo, Vidin and Tunis. In 1872 he was promoted to the rank of Consul General. On 29 October 1882 Svetozar Teodorović de Szent-Endre was ennobled with the title "de (von) Szent-Endre". He retired on 9 July 1884. Svetozar Teodorović de Szent-Endre died in Penzingerstraße 117 (1130 Vienna) on 1 December 1907 and was buried, after a memorial service in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava, in the Hietzing Cemetery (Hietzinger Friedhof, 1130 Vienna) two days later.

description.value: Mihajlo Djordje Teodorović (1815-1877) from Novi Sad (today Serbia) was a wine merchant, who succeeded Pavle Jovanović (1788-1860) in Vienna and organised huge yearly auctions of wine, where he sold thousands of hectoliters. He was the owner of the house Simmeringer Hauptstraße 86 (1110 Vienna) before 1869 (former conscription number 373). Mihajlo Djordje Teodorović died on 4 March 1877 at the age of 62 in his house in Simmeringer Hauptstraße 86 (1110 Vienna), and was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 6 March 1877. The names of his family members are: his wife Babette Teodorović, his son Konstantin Teodorović, his daughter Danica Ostojić, her husband Djordje Ostojić (1831-1901) and his granddaughter Zora Ostojić.

depictions.title: The Roth-Theodorovic Pistol

description.value:
Vasa Teodorović (1851-1919) was born in Stari Sivac (today Serbia) on 24 April 1851. He was an engineer, inventor, merchant and the President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in Vienna from 1907 to 1913. Since 1 July 1889 he and Max Mylius had the joint Company "Theodorović & Cie" (Stephansplatz 7, 1010 Vienna). Vasa Teodorović was the owner of several patents. Amongst others he patented and produced, together with the industrialist Georg Roth (1834-1903), the Roth-Theodorovic pistol in 1895. It was a long-recoil, locked-breech, single or double-action semi-automatic pistol.   
Vasa Teodorović married Anna Wilhelmine Hlouvitschka on 4 November 1880. They had two sons, Teodor (1893) and Milan (1887), and a daughter Olga (1888). Vasa Teodorović died in Mariahilferstraße 27 (1060 Vienna) on 15 March 1919 and was buried two days later in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).

description.value: Djordje Teodorović von Maligrad (1830-1889) was an Austrian Major General Major. He was Knight of the Leopold Order and the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class. Moreover, Djordje Teodorović von Maligrad was decorated with the Military Merit Cross with War decoration. Djordje Teodorović von Maligrad died in his apartment in Margaretenstraße 10 (1040 Vienna) on 19 April 1889 at the age of 59. He was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).

depictions.title: Totenbeschaubefund der Tikiana Teronjak vom 20. Jänner 1917 (Copyright Metropolis von Austria)

description.value: Tikiana Teronjak wurde 1845 in Kirlibaba geboren. Sie war Landwirtin. Tikiana Teronjak litt an Marasmus und starb am 20. Jänner 1917 im Spital des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn an einer Herzparalyse. Sie wurde am 20. Jänner 1917 beschaut und sie sollte am 22. Jänner beerdigt werden. ------------ Tikiana Teronjak was born in Kirlibaba in 1845. She was a farmer. Tikiana Teronjak suffered from marasmus and died of a heart paralysis in the hospital of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn on the 20th of January 1917. She was examined on the 20th of January 1917 and she was to be buried on the 22nd of January.

depictions.title: Bust of Nikola Tesla in the "Technisches Museum" (Vienna)
Nikola Tesla (1856-1943)

description.value: Nikola Tesla (1856-1943) was a Serbian inventor and engineer, who discovered and patented the rotating magnetic field, the basis of most alternating-current machinery. He also developed the three-phase system of electric power transmission. Nikola Tesla was born in Smiljan (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in the family of the Serbian Orthodox Priest Mliutin Tesla and his wife Djuka. He immigrated to the United States of America in 1884 and sold the patent rights to his system of alternating-current dynamos, transformers, and motors to George Westinghouse (1846-1914). In 1891 he invented the Tesla coil, an induction coil widely used in radio technology. George Westinghouse used Tesla's alternating current system to light the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893. This success was a factor in their winning the contract to install the first power machinery at Niagara Falls, which bore Tesla's name and patent numbers. The project carried power to Buffalo by 1896. Nikola Tesla died in New York on Orthodox Christmas, 7 January 1943. Despite the fact that Nikola Tesla had never studied in Vienna, but in the Polytechnic Institute in Graz, the Council of Professors at the Viennese College of Technology ("Technische Hochschule") in Vienna (now TU Vienna) awarded Nikola Tesla for his work with the honorary Dr title on 19 June 1907. The official announcement of this PhD was on 3 March 1908. After the unveiling of the Nikola Tesla's bust, sculpted by Ivan Meštrović (1883-1962), at the Vienna Technical Museum ("Technisches Museum Wien") on 29 June 1952, this Museum organised a conference on Nikola Tesla from 6 September to 13 September 1953. The Council Committee for Culture ("Gemeinderatsausschuß für Kultur") of the City of Vienna named a street, Teslagasse, in the 21st Viennese districts after him on 15 October 1952.

description.value: Petrea Ursaka wurde 1858 in Borna-Kondreni geboren. Er war Landwirt. Petrea Ursaka litt an einem Bronchialkatarrh und starb am 3. Februar 1917 im Flüchtlingslager Oberhollabrunn an einer Herzlähmung. Er wurde am 3. Februar 1917 beschaut und sollte am 5. Februar 1917 beerdigt werden. ----------- Petrea Ursaka was born in Borna-Kondreni in 1858. He was a farmer. Petrea Ursaka suffered from bronchial catarrh and died of heart paralysis in the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn on the 3rd of February 1917. He was examined on the 3rd of February 1917 and was to be buried on the 5th of February 1917.

description.value: Jelena Utješenović (1840-1870) was born in Ruma (today Serbia) in the family von Mladenović. She was married to Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski (1817-1890), a Serbian politician and poet. Jelena Utješenović died in their Viennese home in Berggasse 4 (1090 Vienna) on 23 May 1870 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) in the same grave with her son Milan, who had died in 1867.

depictions.title: Ognjeslav Utješenović-Ostrožinski 1855
Utješenović Coat of Arms

description.value:
Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski (1817-1890) was a Serbian politician and poet, who was born in Ostrožin (today Croatia) at the Military Frontier. As an educated lawyer, he worked firstly in the Croatian Parliament as associate of Ban Josip Jelačić (1801-1859). In 1856 he was appointed to ministerial secretary in Vienna and from 1862 to 1867 he worked as an advisor to the Croatian Court Chancellery. Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski held a title of Court Councillor ("Hofrat"). In his Viennese years he was very active in the social life among the Viennese Serbs. He was one of the initiators of the foundation of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in 1860 as well as its second President from 1864 to 1870. Following Vuk Stefanović Karadžić's death in 1864, Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski, Jovan Subotić (1817-1886) and Franz Xaver Ritter von Miklosich (1813-1891) founded a committee, which took care for the release of Vuk's unpublished manuscripts as well as new editions of already published works and of his family. The first in a series of these works was the fifth book "Serbian Folk Songs", published in 1865, on the first anniversary of Vuk's death. During his stay in Vienna, Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski's son Milan (1867) and wife Jelena (1870) died. From 1875 to 1886 Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski was the governor (župan) of the Varaždin County and retired in 1886.  In 1884 the Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) decorated him with the Order of Leopold, and at the same time he was ennobled as "Ritter von" with the title "Ostrožinski". He received also the Order of Franz Josef. Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski died in Zagreb in 1890. 
In Vienna he published manifold works on the subject of the history of the Military Frontier: 
"Die Hauskommunionen der Südslaven: Eine Denkschrift zur Beleuchtung der volkstümlichen Acker- und Familienverfassung des serbischen und des kroatischen Volkes" (1859)
 "Die Militärgränze und die Verfassung: eine Studie über den Ursprung und das Wesen der Militärgränzinstitution und die Stellung derselben zur Landesverfassung" (1861)
"Programm zur Konstituierung des österreichischen Kaiserstaates nach den Prinzipien der konstitutionellen Freiheit und der nationalen Gleichberechtigung aus dem Jahre 1848" (1861)
"Das Donau-Adria-Bahnnetz" (1865)
"Die Naturschätze im nördlichen Croatien" (1879)
"Lebensgeschichte des Kardinals Georg Utiešenović genannt Martinusius: mit dessen Bildnis, Familien-Wappen u. einer Skizze der Ruinen seines Ahnenschlosses; mit Benützung der Akten des K. K. geheimen Haus- Hof- und Staats-Archivs von 1528-1553"  (1881)
He published in Vienna also his poems: 
Вила Острожинска (Volume I, 1845; Volume II, 1871)
Недељко (Volume I, 1860; Volume II, 1888)
Псалми Давидови (1868)

description.value: Jovan Veličković (1818-1863) was a merchant, who was born in Novi Sad (today Serbia). In July 1850 he was the founder of the Company "Bosanetz & Welicskovits" in Lazzenhof 1 (Bauernmarkt 21, 1010 Vienna), together with Stefan Bosanac (1802-1871), in 1850. He was also one of the initiators of the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna in 1860. Jovan Veličković died at the age of 45 on 17 September 1863 in Untere Donaustraße 23 (1020 Vienna) and was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 19 September 1863. The aforesaid company was deleted from the commercial register on 14 November 1866.

description.value: Djordje Veljović (1789-1838) was a Serbian merchant in Vienna and Ottoman citizen. His father was Jovan Veljović (1755-1803). He died in Fleischmarkt 14 (1010 Vienna; the original building does not exist anymore) at the age of 49 on 27 December 1838 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His wife Anastasia was born in Zemun in the family Karamata. She died at the age of 38 in Vienna on 8 July 1831.

depictions.title: Aleksije Vezilić, Essays (Vienna 1792)

description.value: Aleksije Vezilić (1753-1792) was a Serbian poet, who introduced the German Enlightenment to the Serbian people. He attended a teacher's course of Stefan Vujanovski (1743-1829) in 1780. Before that he had learned German and Latin in Budapest (today Hungary). Aleksije Vezilić studied Law in Vienna in 1785. He was teaching German and Latin in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) until 1790. After that he was appointed as school inspector. Aleksije Vezilić published the "Краткоје сочиненије о приватних и публичних делах" (Vienna 1785 and 1792) and the "Краткоје написаније о спокојној жизни" (Vienna 1788 and Buda 1813), which represents the first collection of verses in modern Serbian literature, in the printing house of Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) and Stefan von Novaković. Aleksije Vezilić also wrote a Serbian-German Dictionary entitled "Речник мали Немецко-Сербски" (Vienna 1793), which was published posthumously.

description.value: Gavrilo Vladislav (1789-1849) was born in Petrinja (today Croatia). He was the owner of the Company "G. Wladislaw" in Vienna with the address Fleischmarkt 695 (Fleischmarkt 10, 1010 Vienna) and merchant of canvas. Gavrilo Vladislav had come to Vienna before 1834. He was the chairman of the Board of Viennese Canvas Merchants. He died on 22 February 1849 in house No. 712 (Griechengasse 9, 1010 Vienna) at the age of 60. He was buried on 25 February 1849 in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).

description.value: Gavrilo Vladislav (1825-1888) was a house owner and merchant. He founded his Company "Wladislaw Gabriel" in 1862. Its address was Fleischmarkt 5 (1010 Vienna, the original building does not exist anymore). Before that he was active as an merchant at the same address since 1854. In 1884 Gavrilo Vladislav bought the house in Obere Weißgärberstraße 4 (1030 Vienna) for 65,000 florins. Gavrilo Vladislav died on 3 December 1888 at the age of 63 in his apartment Pragerstraße 10 (Radetzkystraße 10, 1030 Vienna). After his death the Company was lead by his wife Marie Vladislav until its dissolution and deletion from the commercial register on 20 August 1889.

description.value: Jovan Vladislav was a Viennese canvas merchant, who worked in the beginning together with his uncle Gavrilo Vladislav in his company "G. Wladislaw". In 1851 he founded his own Company "Wladislaw's G. Neffe". Its address was Fleischmarkt 695 (Fleischmarkt 10, 1010 Vienna; the original building does not exist anymore). The Company was deleted from the commercial register on 25 July 1866.  Jovan Vladislav was one of the main initiators for the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna in 1860. On 9 December 1860 this Community was founded in his apartment, and Jovan Vladislav was its first Vice President.

depictions.title: Vojinović Coat of Arms

description.value: Djordje Vojinović de Užički (1833-1895) was a Serbian Count, politician and member of the Upper House ("Herrenhaus") in the Austrian Parliament. He was born in Herceg Novi (today Montenegro) in a noble family. Djordje Vojinović studied Law in Vienna and Padua from 1851 to 1853. Djordje Vojinović de Užički studied together with his brother Konstantin in Vienna. They lived at that time in Wieden 15 (today Wiedner Hauptstraße 25, 1040 Vienna; the original building does not exist anymore). He was mayor of Herceg Novi and member of the Dalmatian Parliament since 1867, its Vice-President  from 1870 to 1876 and its President from 1877 to 1895. Djordje Vojinović was also elected two times as member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Parliament in Vienna from 1870 to 1873 and from 1879 to 1891. He became a member of the Upper House ("Herrenhaus") in the Austrian Parliament in 1892. He had very good relations with Serbian diplomats in Vienna as well as with King Nikola of Montenegro (1841-1921) and King Milan Obrenović of Serbia (1854-1901). After the split in the National Party he was one of the founders of the Serbian Independent Party ("Srpska Samostalna Stranka") in the Dalmatian Parliament. In 1884 he received the Commander's Cross of the Order of Franz Josef. Djordje Vojinović died in Zadar (today Croatia) in 1895 and was buried in the Serbian Orthodox Monastery of Savina in his hometown Herceg Novi. He was decorated with the Serbian Grand Officer's Order of Takovo. Djordje Vojinović was a friend of Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria (1858-1889) and helped him to buy the island of Lokrum near Dubrovnik.

depictions.title: Emil Vojinović von Belobrska (1851-1927)
Tomb of the Family Vojinović in the Viennese Central Cemetery

description.value:
Emil Vojinović von Belobrska (1851-1927) was a General of Infantry of Serbian origin and Director of the War Archives ("Kriegsarchiv") in Vienna. After finishing the Theresian Military Academy ("Theresianische Militärakademie") in Wiener Neustadt and the k.u.k. War College, he started his military career. He lectured Strategy and War History at the War College. Emil Vojinović von Belobrska was the Chief of the k.u.k. Evidenzbureau, which was the directorate of the military intelligence of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, from 1895 to 1896. Since 1901 to his retirement in 1916 he was Director of the War Archives ("Kriegsarchiv") in Vienna. In the same year (1916) Emil Vojinović von Belobrska was ennobled with the title of Baron and also became a corresponding member of the Imperial Academy of Sciences in Vienna. He was also ennobled to Hungarian nobility in 1905, when he received the title "von Belobrska". In 1911 Emil Vojinović von Belobrska was promoted to the rank of a General of Infantry. He received the title of Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat") in 1910 and was awarded the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class (1896), the Knight's Cross of the Order of Leopold (1906) and the Grand Cross of the Order of Franz Josef (1908). In 1936 a street in the 13th Viennese district was named after him ("Woinovichgasse"). 
Emil Vojinović von Belobrska died in his apartment in Fasangasse 36 (1030 Vienna) on 13 February 1927 and was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).

depictions.title: Coat of Arms of the Family Vujanovski
German Grammar (Vienna 1772)
The Church History (Vienna 1793)

description.value: Stefan Vujanovski (1743-1829) was a representative of the Enlightenment among the Serbian people. He was born in Brdjani (today Croatia) in 1743. After finishing grammar school in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia), where his teacher was Jovan Rajić (1726-1801), he went to Sopron and then to Vienna in order to study Law. In 1777 he attended courses of Johann Ignaz Melchior von Felbiger (1724-1788) for primary school principals in Vienna. In the same year he was named school principal of all Serbian primary schools in the Zagreb County. In 1792 Stefan Vujanovski was ennobled to Hungarian nobility and moved to Novi Sad (today Serbia). The education reform of the Serbs was only one of a series of reforms carried out in the 1770s, which had far-reaching consequences not only on the legal and political situation of the Serbs, but also on the development of spiritual life. The reforms were implemented through two Regulations (1770 and 1777), then the Declarations (1779) and the Consistory System (1782). One of the measures implemented was the opening of a printing press for publications printed in Cyrillic, which had a positive effect on the spreading of books among the Serbs. The reform of the Serbian primary schools was led by Teodor Janković Mirijevski (1741-1814) in Banat, by Avram Mrazović (1756-1826) in Bačka and by Stefan Vujanovski in Srem, Slavonia and Croatia. They all had first completed courses held by Felbiger for primary school principals in Vienna. Stefan Vujanovski published a German grammar entitled "Немецкаја Граматика" in 1772 at the printing house of Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792), a philological study entitled "Руководство ко правоглаголанију и правописанију" and a short history of the Church for the schools entitled "Кратка историја цркве", both in 1793, at the printing house of Stefan von Novaković in Vienna.

description.value: Andrija Vujatović Šarov (1841-1924) was a lawyer and politician. He was born in Knin (today Croatia) on 15 February 1841. From 1864 to 1867 he studied Law in Vienna. From 1880 Andrija Vujatović Šarov worked as a notary in Kistanje (today Croatia). At the end of 1881 he moved to Knin, where he also worked as a notary. As a founding member of the People's Party ("Narodna Stranka") in Dalmatia he was a member in the Dalmatian Parliament from 1876 to 1883. After the split in the People's Party he founded with other Serbs the Serbian People's Party ("Srpska Narodna Stranka") in 1880. From 1901 to 1907 Andrija Vujatović Šarov was a member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Austrian Parliament in Vienna. In response to the Resolution of Fiume (Rijeka) in 1905, he initiated in October of the same year and signed the so-called Zara Resolution, an agreement on the future co-operation between the Serbian and Croatian political parties. After leaving the Parliament in 1907, Andrija Vujatović Šarov worked again as a notary in Knin. He was honored with the Knight's Cross of the Franz Josef Order in 1906. In 1912 he also received the Montenegrin Danilo Order 3rd class. Andrija Vujatović Šarov died on 15 November 1924 in Knin and was buried in Vrbnik (today Croatia).

depictions.title: Mihailo Vujić (1853-1913)

description.value: Mihailo Vujić (1853-1913) studied Philosophy in Belgrade and later Philosophy and Economy in Leipzig and Berlin, where he received his title of Dr in Philosophy. From 1879 to 1887 he was Professor of Economy at the Great School in Belgrade (the forerunner of the University of Belgrade). Later Mihailo Vujić became Minister of Finance, diplomat in Paris, Minister of Foreign Affairs and Prime Minister from 1901 to 1902. From 1903 to 1906 he was Serbian ambassador in Vienna and later in Berlin and Rome. Mihailo Vujić became a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in 1901.

depictions.title: Field marshal-lieutenant Nikola Vujić (1846-1910)
Tomb of the Family Vujić in the Viennese Central Cemetery

description.value: Nikola Vujić (1846-1910) was an Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant of Serbian origin, who was born in Prigor (today Romania) on 28 September 1846. He received the title of Knight ("Ritter") in 1884 and was promoted to the rank of Major General in 1898. In 1903 Nikola Vujić became Field marshal-lieutenant. In the same year he was appointed to President of the Technical Military Committee. Nikola Vujić retired in 1908 and was honoured with the title of Baron. With his wife Karoline he had a son called Nikola and a daughter called Karolina (married Müller). Nikola Vujić was a corresponding member of the Serbian Royal Academy since 1885 and full member since 15 November 1892. He died in his apartment in Schönburggasse 17 (1040 Vienna) on 12 March 1910 and was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) three days later.

depictions.title: Totenbeschaubefund des Andrä Wallasch vom 03. März 1917 (Copyright Metropolis von Austria)

description.value: Andrä Wallasch wurde 1867 in der Ortschaft Petrantz geboren. Er war Landwirt. Er litt an Darmtuberkulose und starb am 03. März 1917 im Spital des Flüchtlingslagers Oberhollabrunn an Herzlähmung. Andrä Wallasch wurde am 03. März 1917 beschaut und sollte am 05. März 1917 beerdigt werden. --------------- Andrä Wallasch was born in 1867 in the village of Petrantz. He was a farmer. He suffered from intestinal tuberculosis and died of heart paralysis on the 3rd of March 1917 in the hospital of the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn. Andrä Wallasch was examined on the 3rd of March 1917 and was to be buried on the 5th of March 1917.

Februar 1917 im Flüchtlingslager Oberhollabrunn an einem Lungenödem. Er wurde am 20. Februar 1917 beschaut und sollte am 22. Februar 1917 beerdigt werden. -------------- Manoli Wasylyniezuk was born in Raraneze in 1867. He was a farmer. Manoli Wasylyniezuk suffered from chronic bronchial catarrh and died of pulmonary edema on the 20th of February 1917 in the refugee camp Oberhollabrunn. He was examined on the 20th of February 1917 and was to be buried on the 22nd of February 1917.

description.value: Lazar Zaharijević (1828-1904) was born in Kovin (today Serbia). After finishing grammar school in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia), he studied Law in Vienna from 1850 to 1853. Lazar Zaharijević was a friend of all prominent Sebian students in this period, namely Branko Radičević, Djura Daničić, Djordje Natošević, Svetozar Miletić, the future Bishop Teofan Živković and his brother Jovan Živković. In his memoirs he describes his friendship with Branko Radičević, Djura Daničić and Djordje Natošević, with whom he spent almost every evening in the famous "Slavonic Café" (also "Café Gerlovich") of Аndrija Gerlović in Bauernmarkt 5 (1010 Vienna). After finishing his studies, Lazar Zaharijević began to work in 1854 at the court in Arad (today Romania). He was later a jugde and a lawyer.

depictions.title: Coat of Arms of the Family Zamfir

description.value: Jovan Zamfir Junior (1867-1887), the son of Jovan Zamfir (1834-1914), was born on 30 November 1867 in Piaristengasse 41 (1080 Vienna). Like his father he was a pharmacist. Jovan Zamfir Junior was baptised in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt (1010 Vienna) and his godfather was Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880). Jovan Zamfir Junior died at the age of 20 on 4 December 1887 and was buried two days later in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).

description.value: Jovan Zamfir Senior (1834-1914) was the chairman of the Pharmaceutical Assistants Society in Vienna. He was the owner of the pharmacy in Mittelgasse (today Bürgerspitalgasse 14, 1060 Vienna) from 1891 to 1895. Jovan Zamfir was a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in the time of the building of the church in the 1880s and 1890s. His wife Anna died on 14 September 1913 at the age of 76. Jovan Zamfir died on 18 December 1914 at the age of 80 and was buried three days later in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).

description.value: Gedeon Ritter von Zastavniković (1824-1869) was an Austrian Major General of Serbian origin, who was born in Kula (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in 1824. After his military education in Graz he was adjutant of Ban Josip Jelačić (1801-1859). Later, Gedeon Zastavniković became a commander of the Slunj Regiment and commander of the Militay Frontier. After this duty he went to Vienna, where he worked in the Ministry of War. Gedeon Ritter von Zastavniković died on 6 January 1869 at the age of 45 in his apartment Landstraßer Hauptstraße 68 (1030 Vienna) and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).

description.value: Severin Zavišić (1817-1885) was a medical doctor, surgeon and President of Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council in Vienna from 1876 to 1884. He was the owner of several patents for the invention of different instruments in the field of medicine and hygiene. In 1856 Severin Zavišić lived in Fleischmarkt 700/728 (today Fleischmarkt 1, the original building does not exist anymore). He was head physician in the Viennese "Garnisons-Spittal" and archducal Court Physician ("erzherzoglicher Hofarzt") as well as the personal physician of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). Severin Zavišić was honored with the Serbian Takovo Order (1882) and was also a honorary member of the Belgian Life Saving Society. He died in his apartment in Seitenstettengasse 5 (1010 Vienna) on 15 June 1885 at the age of 68. Severin Zavišić was buried on 17 June 1885 in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).

depictions.title: Nikola Zec (1883-1958)
Nikola Zec (1883-1958)

description.value: Nikola Zec (1883-1958) was a Serbian opera singer, who was born in Zagreb on 12 October 1883. He studied at the Viennese Conservatorium. Nikola Zec performed several times in Serbian concerts: on 1 March 1906 the Mercantile Society of the Viennese Serbs ("Serbischer Kaufmännischer Verein") organised a charity concert for the Serbian Orthodox Church and its school in the Ronacher Ballsaal; on 27 January 1908 at the Serbian Students' Association "Zora" in the Kursalon (Stadtpark) and together with the famous Serbian composer and violinist Petar Stojanović (1877-1957) at the Academy of St. Sava in the Hotel Continental (Taborstraße 2, 1020 Vienna) on 26 January 1925. From 1907 to 1912 he was a member of the Viennese Volksoper and then of a theatre in Prague. Since 1916 he was a member of the Hofoper (today Wiener Staatsoper) in Vienna, where he had an appearance as a guest in 1912. According to the Archive of the Wiener Staatsoper, Nikola Zec had 1121 appearances on stage from 1912 to 1940. His first appearance was as "Marcel" in "Les Huguenots" and his last on 8 June 1940 as "Cancian" in "I quattro rusteghi". Nikola Zec lived in an apartment in Otto Bauer Gasse 2 (1060 Vienna) and died in Bad Aussee on 9 July 1958. He was buried seven days later in the Hietzing Cemetery (Hietzinger Friedhof, 1130 Vienna).

description.value: Danilo Žefarović (1736-1806) was the son of Hristofor Žefarović's sister, whom he adopted. He was born in Thessalonica (today Greece) in 1736. Danilo  Žefarović came to Vienna in 1755 and after some time beeing in the circle of Orthodox Greeks and Serbs, he converted to the Roman Catholic faith. Danilo Žefarović, together with Johann Graf von Fries (1719-1785), founded a trading company on the Danube in 1777 for the trade in the Ottoman lands. Danilo Žefarović was raised to Austrian nobility on 21 March 1782. He also bore the title of Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat"). In 1761 he married Katharina Preinl. In Žefarović's possession were at least five houses in Vienna, including today's House of Music in Annagasse 20 (1010 Vienna), which he had built in 1790. Intresting is that this house was from 1923 to 1941 and from 1948 to 1957 the seat of the Yugoslav embassy. Daniel Žefarović built the house "zur weißen Rose" in Fleischmarkt 16 (1010 Vienna) at the beginning of the 19th century (ca. 1800) and died there on 3 May 1806. On the facade, among other ornamental reliefs, there is to be seen the coat of arms of the family Žefarović above the gate. His wife Katharina lived there with the family until her death in 1814. The house remained the family's property until 1925. Numerous generations, the descendants of Daniel and Katharina Žefarović, who still live in Austria today, have were civil servants, officers, lawyers and professors. Among them is for example Victor Leopold Ritter von Zepharovich (1830-1890), Professor of Mineralogy at the University of Prague.

description.value: Georgije Žefarović (1722-1752) was a Serbian painter, engraver and coppersmith. He was the nephew of Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753), who had appointed him as his successor. Georgije Žefarović came on his invitation to Vienna in 1740s and begun his studies at the Viennese Academy of Fine Arts on 5 October 1744. Some authors are pointing out that Georgije Žefarović was the first Serbian educated painter. Only three of his coppersmith works are known, which were all made in Vienna. Georgije Žefarović died in Vienna a the age of 30 in Salzgries 9 (1010 Vienna) on 24 December 1752.

depictions.title: Privileges for the Serbian Peoople by the Habsburg Rulers (Vienna 1743)
Saint Sava with the Saints of the Dynasty Nemanjić (Vienna, ca. 1750-1753)
Stemmatography (Vienna 1741)

description.value:
Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753) was a coppersmith and engraver, painter and monk, who was born ca. 1690 in Dojran (then Ottoman Empire, today Republic of North Macedonia). As a church painter of the Metropolis of Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) he came to Vienna in 1741. His works were printed by the Viennese coppersmith Thomas Meßmer. Until 1753 he was intermittently in Vienna, when he finally moved to Moscow and died in the same year. Initially, Hristofor Žefarović had come to Vienna with his nephew Georgije Žefarović (1722-1752). Georgije Žefarović was the first Serbian educated painter, but unfortunately died early. Hristofor Žefarović then adopted his sister's son Danilo Žefarović (1736-1806), who was appointed as his only successor in his testament.
He printed his most famous work entitled "Stemmatography" ("Stematografija") in 1741. The role model for his publication was Pavel Ritter Vitezović's (1652-1713) heraldic book "Stemmatography" from the year 1702. Hristofor Žefarović translated from Latin into Church Slavonic and created several engravings and pictures, which are: the portraits of the Serbian Saints of the Middle Ages, especially the rulers and Saints of the Nemanjić Dynasty, the coats of arms of the 56 Slavic and other Balkan countries and coats of arms of different cities and states. The importance of the "Stemmatography" is remarkable, not only for the the Serb people, but also for all the other Southern Slavs. This book played an extremely important role in the spiritual awakening and enlightenment of the Serbs in the 18th century. It is also worth mentioning that it is dedicated to the Serbian Patriarch Arsenije IV Jovanović Šakabenta (1698-1748). In 1743 Hristofor Žefarović wrote the first translation of imperial privileges for the Serbs by the Habsburg rulers Leopold I (1640-1705), Josef I (1678-1711), Charles VI (1685-1740) and Maria Theresia (1717-1780) and printed them in Vienna.

description.value: Dušan Živanović (1853-1937) was a Serbian architect, who was born in Senta (today Serbia). He studied Architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") from 1871 to 1873 as a student of the famous Professor Teophil von Hansen (1813-1891). During his studies he lived in Theresianumgasse 13 (1040 Vienna) from 1871 to 1872. Dušan Živanović worked later as an architect in the Ministry of Infrastructure of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes in Belgrade. He designed many public buildings and Orthodox churches, among which the most important is the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral Church of the Holy Trinity in Banja Luka (today Republic of Srpska, Bosnia and Hercegovina) from 1925 to 1929.

depictions.title: Jovan Živković Fruškogorski (1826-1902)

description.value: Jovan Živković Fruškogorski (1826-1902) was a Serbian politician and nobleman in Austria-Hungary. After 1848 he finished his Law Studies at the University of Vienna. He was Vicecount of the County Syrmien (Srem) and member of the Court of Seven (Supreme Court). Jovan Živković Fruškogorski was the Chief of the Department of Internal Affairs in the Croatian-Slavonian administration and also deputy of the Ban. He was honored as Knight of the Order of Saint Stephen and the Order of the Iron Crown 2nd class in 1880, when he was ennobled with the title of Baron with the predicate "Fruškogorski". Jovan Živković Fruškogorski died in Zagreb in 1902.

depictions.title: Pantelejmon Živković 1839

description.value: Pantelejmon Živković (1795-1851) was a Serbian Bishop of Dalmatia, Timișoara and Budapest. After attending grammar school and finishing the studies of Theology in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia), he studied Law in Vienna. He was Bishop of Dalmatia from 1834 to 1836. After that he was named Bishop of Budapest. Finally, in 1839 Pantelejmon Živković was appointed as Bishop of Timișoara. He was honored by the Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) with the distinction Knight Commander of the Order of Saint Stephen in 1848. He was also Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat"). Pantelejmon Živković died in Kleine Schulenstraße 850 (today Domgasse 9, 1010 Vienna) on 22 March 1851.

depictions.title: Teodor Zurunić (1866-1951) in 1910

description.value:
Teodor Zurunić (1866-1951) was born in Stari Majdan (today Bosnia and Hercegovina) on 30 January 1866. After attending the grammar school in Novi Sad (today Serbia), he studied Law in Vienna from 1884 to 1888 and was promoted to Dr of Law. Teodor Zurunić was a civil servant in the department for Bosnia and Herzegovina in the Ministry of Finance since 1888. In 1898 he was awarded the Knight's Cross of the Franz Josef Order. On 31 October 1913 he received the Order of the Iron Crown 2nd class. In December 1896 Teodor Zurunić was promoted to the position of secretary in the Ministry of Finance. At that time he was the first official from Bosnia and Herzegovina to reach this rank in the Austro-Hungarian administration. He was the first doctor of Law from this very province.  In February 1903 Teodor Zurunić was promoted to Governing Councillor ("Regierungsrat") in the same Ministry. Since September 1896 he was lecturing the Serbo-Croatian language at the Theresian Military Academy ("Theresianische Militärakademie") in Wiener Neustadt. In October 1909 Teodor Zurunić was promoted to the rank of Court Councillor ("Hofrat"). In April 1912 he was promoted to "Sektionschef" in the Provincial government ("Landesregierung") of Bosnia and Herzegovina in Sarajevo. In November 1913 he became the head of the administrative department in this government. 
By his own demand Teodor Zurunić was sent to retirement on 15 November 1915. 
Teodor Zurunić was for decades the secretary of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in Vienna. He wrote the chapter on domestic art and handicraft entitled "Haus- und Kunstgewerbe" in the series "Die österreichisch-ungarische Monarchie in Wort und Bild: Bosnien und Herzegowina" (Vienna 1901). Moreover, he published a book on the Bosnian economy entitled "Die bosnische Pflaume. Eine Handelsstudie" (Vienna 1895). This book was printed in same year in English translation "The Bosnian Plum. A Commercial Study".
Teodor Zurunić married Baronin Olga Schröckinger (born on 19 March 1864) in the Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 11 January 1900. His address at that time was Marokkanergasse 18 (1030 Vienna). His best man was the journalist Djordje Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota (1843-1908). They had three daughters:
Tatjana Zurunić was born in Baden (today Austria) on 8 July 1900 and was baptised in the Church of St. Sava on 12 August. Roksanda Zurunić was born on 7 August 1902 in Baden and baptised in the Church of St. Sava on 7 September. Jelenka Zurunić was born on 7 July 1904 in Weikersdorf near Baden and baptised in the Church of St. Sava on 7 August. The godfather of all three daughters was Djordje Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota. Tatjana studied at the University of Vienna from 1918 to 1922. On 23 October 1922 she married the Yugoslav diplomat Konstantin Fotić (1891-1959) in the Church of St. Sava in Vienna. Roksanda finished also her studies at the University of Vienna. Zurunić's youngest daughter Jelenka was promoted to Dr of Philosophy at the University of Vienna on 20 July 1926.

types.description:
This research project focuses on one of the aspects of the history and presence of Orthodox Christians, and in particular of the Orthodox Serbs, in Vienna. Quite often the opinion emerges in the contemporary public discourse that the Orthodox Christians have come to Austria for the first time in the wake of the so-called "Gastarbeiterbewegung" of the 1960s and 1970s. However, their history and presence in Austria dates well back to the 17th century. In fact, according to the Austro-Hungarian population census of 1910, more than 2,000,000 Serbs lived in the Habsburg monarchy: in Hungary a total of 1,106,471, in Bosnia and Herzegovina 825,338 and in Dalmatia 105,000.
This research project uses biographical data on the Orthodox Serbs in Vienna in the period from 1741 until 1918 in order to illustrate how the Orthodox began to migrate to the Habsburg Empire, how Orthodox merchants settled in Vienna and how they integrated into Viennese society of that time. On the basis of meticulously researched data in Austrian archives the life of famous Serbs in Vienna is reconstructed. Their places of dwelling and action are localised and embedded into a customised OpenAtlas database with an online Geoportal, which will be open to the interested public at the end of the project.
This project aims to gain a better understanding of contemporary developments and future trends in Orthodox Christianity based on scholarly research on famous Serbian personalities of the 18th and 19th centuries in detail, which were already integrated into Austrian society at that time in Vienna as well as in Austria in general.
